Review title: How a normal person reacts to a situation under tension and finds a way out?
Review_body: How should a normal person behave in an abnormal situation? Especially when he has to face a contract killer, it's not as simple as it seems. The movie depicts this picture in a very sensible manner.The movie is backed by two great actors Jammie Fox and the ultimate Tom Cruise. I think the cast was perfect because the slot of taxi driver was perfect for a relatively new actor and that of Vincent needed to be a tough guy who has a lot of experience in acting. This is a perfect blend of characters. The expressions shown by Jammie Fox are exactly of a common person watching a dead body for the first time. Tom Cruise has shown a phenomenal presentation of acting, to act as a professional killer is not a simple job. Some of the best quotes are, "Get in the car". That was a good one.The movie just shows how a normal cab driver reacts in an unusual situation and helps save a lady. I think this is a great piece of work by the whole group so as to bring such an outstanding movie.

Well, i have seen the movie Collateral 2 times, and let me tell you it was worth it. Tom Cruise has once again showed his competence in the acting business, not to mention the excellent performance of Jamie Foxx, who represented a simple taxi driver, who has noting to worry about, who has very good relations with his clients, and is loved by them. Tom Cruise, on the other hand has an role of a coldblooded assassin, Vincent, who has no feelings, who does not bind with his 'clients', and is certainly not loved by them:) So about the movie: it really expresses emotions of an scared citizen who has found suddenly himself in the hands of an person who doesn't care for human feelings ,compation, and pure love. Max is a person who probably represents every one of us, and what would we do in the given situation. Vincent, on the other hand, he is an assassin, and what can you expect of an assassin? Only one thing is expected from an assassin-cold bloodiness. That is the basic principle of being an assassin, and let me tell you, Tom Cruise has played it flawlessly, really, I can't think of anyone who might play it better, congratulations to Michaell Mann for that excellent, one of a kind movie.

Simply beautiful to look at  the cinematography and Jada Pinkett-Smith. The soundtrack to this film  although stunningly understated  was sublime. The pace could be misinterpreted as sluggish, I however applaud the uncompromisingly 'un-Hollywood' rhythm Collateral has from start to finish. 'Action hungry' punters might feel a little short changed with this offering, because although it does provide beautifully executed battles  chiefly in the nightclub  Collateral is essentially a film that gravitates around the interplay between the two leads, near perfect visual sequences and a soundtrack that at times sounds angelic.My few snipes with this film are minor, yet worth mentioning if only to ask why such things were left in1. Vincent's trousers need lengthening  not a good look wardrobe guys! 2. NONE of the actors can run properly, although watching Foxx try to run offered me a huge slice of amusement and dramatic relief. 3. The only fight scene  fleeting though it was - between Foxx and Cruise looked ridiculousalmost comical. I expected to see an action bubble saying "POW" or "KABAM!". 4. As the film hurtles towards its culmination in the offices, Cruise suddenly adopts a Jason Vorhees-esquire approach towards his body posture, mannerisms and movementit just seemed a little odd to me. 5. The final scene  as the tube descends into the night - looked like the editor didn't quite know how to end the film smoothly, so didn't bother trying. 6. Plus, I didn't quite know if Cruise died in the end or was simply taking a napI just hope he didn't miss his stop, is anything more annoying?Aside from all these downers, I thoroughly loved so many things about this film, and wish more Hollywood films would adopt a similar laid back approach to future thrillers.Stunning!

Review title: One of the best thrillers I have ever watched!!
Review_body: Let me start out by saying that this movie is a masterpiece, it's got everything from a killer soundtrack, beautiful visuals, a strong casting of actors, a deep storyline that keeps you drawn to the screen at all times and action that is memorable for years to come. Collateral is a strong piece of work that came from Mann since Heat, he really brought everything to life in this movie, the way he shows off L.A. can blow your mind away with how well he angled everything to look perfect. Not only are the visuals great, but when you get a killer movie with a strong casting such as Cruise, Foxx, Smith etc. it's no wonder this movie turned out so strong. Most people didn't like how the ending of the movie happened, but if you pay close attention, Max(Jamie Foxx) out smarted Vincent(Tom Cruise) and came out to be the top dog in this chase, he simply tricked Vincent by stepping into the view of one window then quickly changed when the lights went out and had the upper hand when Vincent was blindly shooting, it's little details like that that are in the movie which makes this such a strong movie. I still wont remember the club scene where everything goes to hell basically, it's one of those moments where anyone can get killed and it has you on the edge of your seat. All in all this movie is a work of art, it's got everything from great sound, visual, acting, storyline and it's at a decent length running at 2 hours, do us a favor and check out this movie, you wont be disappointed.
Another one where it makes no sense how such a poor film attracted so many high profile actors.

Review title: One of The Best Movies I Have Seen In Years
Review_body: The movie Collateral is a very entertaining piece of film work. The plot line of this movie is not one that would entice many, but the way that Jamie Foxx and Tom Cruise executed their roles is so unprecedented that it was a film that many people saw as "edge-of-your-seat" material. The plot line was where a cabbie had to drive a hit-man around so that he could make his raids. I was on the edge of my seat when Max (Jamie Foxx) discovered that Vincent's (Tom Cruise) final stop of the 5 stops that he had to make was to kill Annie, (Jada Pinkett Smith) the woman that Max met when he took her to her office downtown. I won't go into details because I want to keep the movie suspenseful. Also, I was a bit more impressed with Jamie Foxx's role in the movie because he is mainly a comedian, but he did very well in the role of a thriller. Tom Cruise is an actor who performs in a lot of different genres of films. Many people who watch these kinds of movies will not see them as realistic, but there are plenty of cabbies just like Max that could get suckered in as a chauffeur for a hit-man like Vincent. Overall, I thought that Collateral was a very good movie and I would recommend it to anyone that liked suspenseful thrillers. This is not the kind of movie that will scare people too much, but it is so chronological and entertaining that it would keep someone in the living room watching it from start to finish.

Review title: Collateral success on the big screen.
Review_body: Collateral is basically about a taxi driver named Max (Jamie Foxx - Ray) who gives a lift to a hit-man named Vincent (Tom Cruise - War of the Worlds). But once Max realises what sort of person Vincent really is he starts to panic, but is unable to end this awful night. The film ends with Max rescuing the girl he dropped off just before he picked up Vincent. The performances from the lead actors are superb. They get into the role extremely well and pulled off what could have been a major flop. However the actors cannot get all the credit. The film has been made visually beautiful. Although it may not be as visually stunning as a Baz Lurhmann film, Collateral has some of those special moments that can take your breathe away (the wolves scene). And all this is entwined with an ensemble of Jazz music that just fits perfectly with the story.I'll admit, it does have it's flaws (would you take a hit-man to see your mother with little fuss), but overall it is a marvellous film, and a must see for all.J Davies

Review title: One of the worst movies of Tom Cruise I have seen
Review_body: Before telling about this movie I would like to question Tom Cruise why does he accept such movies(even Lions for Lambs was very boring). The movie had no story. It is totally dull and boring right from the minute one. The plot has very little to offer. The movie theme is totally dark. Only a few shots of Tom Cruise are a bit interesting. Otherwise as a whole the movie has nothing to offer. It totally lacks pace except for the last ten minutes. All the murders are very boring. The movie does not look like a motion picture at all. Even the camera work isn't right. Only you should watch it for the performances for Tom Cruise and Foxx. I would not recommend this to anyone unless they want to waste around 90 min of their life on this stupid movie.I hope that I would see Tom Cruise in some meaningful movie at least in the near future.

Jamie Foxx plays a Taxi Driver who all of a sudden gets caught up on the pathway of a contract killer, played by Tom Cruise. When the Taxi Driver witnesses the first hit, the Taxi Driver attempts to escape, but the contract killer makes him cooperate by brainwashing him. Should the Taxi Driver fail to comply, the contract killer will dispose of the Taxi Driver mercilessly. The taxi driver's life takes a change for the worse as he's forced to make 4 more stops through strict cooperation of the contract killer, and the LAPD are already trying to investigate the killings done by this contract killer. When the taxi driver realizes that one of his customers is targeted to be hit by this contract killer, the Taxi Driver attempts to make a heroic approach to prevent the hit from happening.This movie surely shows the dark realities of being a taxi driver, which leaves us one lesson--Never trust anyone, question everything, if you are a Taxi Driver.

Now this is a excellent blend of popcorn entertainment and thought-provoking story telling. We have Tom Cruise playing calm, collective hit-man Vincent who is taking a backseat to submissive cab driver Max (Jamie Foxx) as he guides him around town to take out five targets within a night with the police on both men's trail as Vincent unintentionally leave bloodshed behind him where ever he goes. Michael Mann takes us to the dark and grimy yet strikingly beautiful sides of Los Angeles for a ride we will never forget. The digital cinematography gives the film a crisp, clean vision of the City of Angels and presents it in breathtaking fashion while balanced out with nightmarish landscapes the duo have placed themselves into during the course of the night, and does that in a sense of real-time filming. The two leads are great and fill out every aspect of their characters in their roles and the absorbing banter between them is definitely the real action within this film. 10/10

Review title: One of the recent best crime dramas
Review_body: I will start by saying this is a VERY good movie. Tom Cruise and Jamie Foxx give wonderful performances. Tom Cruise portrays the dark, mysterious hired killer, Vincent, and give off the enigmatic being that he is beautifully. Jamie Foxx does an amazing job being funny and serious at the same time. I wouldn't be surprised if Jamie Foxx wins a best supporting role for this movie. Esthetically speaking, this movie looks awesome, as do most of Michael Mann's films. The cinematography is nearly flawless and I was especially impressed with the birdseye views of L.A. downtown and the Taxi riding. I was also impressed by the gun acting done by Tom Cruise. He makes shooting a gun look really cool. You can say whatever you want about the ending but I don't think it really takes away from anything about this movie. If you liked "Heat" and are looking for a movie that not only develops characters through superb dialogue and great action scenes...definitely check out this movie.

After seeing the high average rating of viewers of IMDb, and the promising idea for an original action movie, I watched this in theatre tonight.After the first killing in the movie (with the guy dropping on the cab), I already got a bad feeling. After some more dialogues it got worse. Yep, another wannabe 'intelligent' action movie, with a few jokes throw in, because we don't want it to be too excited. Really cheesy 'psychological' dialogues, and some really horrible unnatural flow of the story (the taxi driver seeing the same girl he talked to earlier is on the list (chance of that is like 1 out of 867, 545,124. The guy chasing Tom Cruise himself, why inform the police right? etc. etc.)I can really enjoy an action movie, but this one really tries way too hard, but it worked for most people i guess?4 out of 10

WOW! No words to describe the magnitude of "Collateral". Excellent screenplay, perfectly directed, with a great cast. Can you get better than that? Michael Mann is the master of LA crime films, and one of the best directors out there. And "Collateral" just proves all of this.Containing various elements from noir film's (my favorite genre), this is a powerful dark look at contemporary L.A. at night. Micahel Mann, as always, does an excellent job in analyzing each characters emotional state during the various different moments of the film. With an awesome performance by Cruise, and even better by Foxx, the film really catches you, just can't run away from the story! One of my favorite films! Definitely recommend it!

Review title: This is a very good thriller
Review_body: The rarity of an unpredictable thriller. This is a very good movie that almost never sells out to the classic action genre where the good guy never gets hit and every one else dies. And they didn't bring someone alive for that last harrowing moment. Cruise is interesting and complex. The initial scenes with the cab ride are well developed. A relationship for which I was actually interested. Very well done overall. The only let down was the club scene where just a few too many bad guys were killed without a scratch to Cruise. The scene where our hero advises the heroine of her eminent demise was a little weak in its cinematic assumptions ("He knows where you are!" .... How did he know he knew where she was? Could he see that he was looking at the phone?) And why would a guy like Vincent waste his time trying to cut the power. Did the lack of light somehow help him. I think it just made the job harder. He was a psychopathic killer. That part didn't make sense. Otherwise, very well done.

tom cruise is just perfect as the mean, heartless hit-man. and jamie foxx holds up pretty well. even though the movie is played dead-serious, there's a certain humor that just comes from the situation they're in. it's just funny to see vincent's character, an expert hit-man, who seems to have everything under control, suddenly slip up with his first target, which is where the excitement begins. all in all, it was a great movie. but i have to admit that, probably like most of us who've seen it, i was actually rooting for vincent's character the whole time.i give it a 10, hands down.

Michael Mann is a master of realism. Movies don't get much better than this. Collateral is a movie that has a little something for everyone. It has extremely entertaining action for the action fan, it has subtle humor for the Jamie Foxx fans, it has hard drama for those fans who like to believe what they are seeing could actually happen, but the best feature of this movie had to be its suspense. Mann had me on the edge of my seat from the opening scene of the film to the very end. Tom Cruise of course handed in another impeccable performance. It was actually quite refreshing to see him as the anti-hero. However, being a big TC fan, I continually found myself cheering for him. Tom makes you believe that the character Vincent is real. Mark Ruffalo gave in a star-turning performance as the lead detective hunting down Foxx and Cruise. This is the kind of role that will turn him into a strong supporting star for many years to come. Ruffalo also made you believe that his character Detective Raymond Fanning was a real person and Ruffalo made him very easy to relate to. Michael Mann of course made all of this happen through his masterful camera-work and location filming. Mann is a master of on site filming and makes you feel as though you are in the cab with Cruise and Foxx during a normal LA nite. Mann's past experiences with Manhunter and Heat are relevant in this film and made it more enjoyable to watch. Last but not least is Jamie Foxx. Jamie played the unbelievably real cab driver Max Durocher. 3/4 of the way through, Foxx stole this movie. His character had an epiphany and I soon found myself cheering for his character of Max. This is the kind of role that will put Foxx in the position of starring roles for many years to come. Mann was also able to amp up the feel of this movie with an unbelievable soundtrack, featuring a bone chilling hit from Audioslave, Shadow on the Sun. The audio in this movie is second to none and the soundtrack is a great investment. Mann's signature camera-work was a joy to watch; which is probably why I already went to see it three times. His scene with the coyotes was the best scene in movies all summer. It gave me goosebumps and let me know that something big was about to happen. It's not often that a director can evoke such emotion from such an intelligent viewer. Overall, this was probably the best movie of the summer. Mann did nothing wrong. His mix of characters and actors portraying them perfectly,his haunting soundtrack, stunning visuals, masterful camera-work and real-life dialog make this movie one which will imitated and looked up to for decades to come.

Excellent Action Movie. Tom Cruise is Cold as hell and Jamie Foxx plays his unwilling sidekick.This flick is a keeper. Since the plot line is already on IMDb...Cruise is an assassin who Foxx picks up in his cab.Cruise kills a lot of peopleLots of action.I also enjoyed the second disk in the set with "the making of" or whatever they called it. Very interesting process shots. Mann must be a totally anal dude, but he puts out an excellent product.Mann doesn't have a lot of screen credit, the Miami Vice Series, Last of the Mohicans, and Heat stick out, but he does an excellent job on this film. Both my fiancé and I agreed, this one is one of the best we've seen this year.The only fault I see is the plot becomes predictable at the end...

Review title: Collateral is one of the year's top mainstream films
Review_body: Collateral is one of those films that pulls you in through characterization and then blows your mind with events. This was easily Tom Cruise's best performance, as Vincent the cold-hearted killer for hire. Foxx was top notch as well, as the cab driver Max thrust into events and situations out of his control. This Tom Cruise doubter has been thoroughly convinced of his place as one of modern Hollywood's true superstars and Foxx's star will only continue to rise after this performance. The characterizations provided by these two men are first rate and speak loudly to any moviegoer who has contemplated the direction of their life as these two characters do. The lives of both Vincent and Max become so intertwined by the end of the movie the death of one of them is a rebirth of the other.The camera work was the right blend of intensity and subtlety. The city of Los Angeles is on display in this flick like never before as a dark, yet colorful, backdrop for our characters and events. The camera makes love to L.A. with beautiful tracking shots and pans over the Christmas tree lights that are the city. By the end of the movie, one realizes that this film is as much an homage to the city, as a suspenseful character-driven action piece. Also integral to the feel of the film is the original motion picture soundtrack by various artists. Techno and Electronica beats seem to fit nice and snug next to Hispanic flavored rock, alternative, jazz, easy listening, and movie-themed-tracks. Despite the eclectic nature of the music in this film it all feels strangely "right" and fits the movie as perfect as any hardcore instrumental soundtrack would fit an historical epic, for example.With all that, and more, this film is one of the best I have seen all year (if not THE best). If you love film, acting, suspense, or the technical aspect of film-MAKING, go see this movie NOW.

Review title: Pleasantly surprised and satisfied by this character piece (some spoilers!)
Review_body: I don't like Tom Cruise, and I don't like Jamie Foxx. I thought the former was empty and pretentious, and I thought the latter was empty and cheap. I went to see this film out of obligation, and I wasn't entertained by the trailer or any of the clips. However after the screening, I thoroughly enjoyed this film and their performances. The whole time LA was described rather negatively, and the events show a grim city, BUT the cinematography was beautiful and showed a glamorous city. Why is this so appealing? I don't know, but these two contrasting portrayals of LA complemented each other. Second, many things were very unrealistic and illogical in this film. There's no way to predict LA traffic, esp around the downtown, west Hollywood, ktown area!!! Who would hire a killer to do this in kind of job without an accomplice? How do BOTH people walk away from that kind of accident? OK minus those annoying details, the jewel of this piece lies in the characters. THey really stayed true to themselves, and their dependence as well as the inevitable riddance of one or the other made this film. The struggle was definitely complex between Vincent & Max. Darwin was used jokingly throughout the film, but it really was central to their decisions, esp. Max at the end. Props to Mark Ruffalo, who's always wonderful and Mr. Cruise, who blew me away and made me fall desperately for his character (except for some cheesy background info). Oh and Mr. Mann, no one could have shot the club scene more eloquently, artistically, yet accurately. The plot had some problems, but the story had great characters, which shows this film deserves more than being referred to as an action genre piece. 8/10

'Collateral' is not your average summer film. Tom Cruise and Jamie Foxx give stellar performances as Vincent the contract killer and as Max the cabbie (respectively). Can't forget Jada Pinkett-Smith as Annie! Michael Mann (one of my favorite directors) is at his top form. The story is original, the characters are very well developed and complex as is the story. The Stuart Beattie screenplay is simply awesome and it never lags at any point in time. The best part of the film is that the dialogue and action is perfectly balanced. This film doesn't have too much action or too much dialogue. Like I said before, the balance is perfect. The characters have real conversations that exposes who they truly are and what their lives really are. Tom Cruise is (again) simply perfect, but Jamie Foxx is a real surprise. He's kind of the 'it' guy of 2004. Mann shot the film in hi-def, which has a huge payoff, making the image crisp and clear (considering the entire film takes place at night). The city of L.A. seems to come alive and looks vibrant as ever (remember 'Heat?'), thanks to the hi-def. Don't miss out on this one, it is truly a masterpiece.***** out of ***** This film is stunning.

Collateral is not just an action movie. It's not just a suspense movie either. The good thing about Collateral is that it spans genres through its story and does it effectively. Tom Cruise's character is convincing, although Jamie Foxx does a better job at capturing the audience's attention.This movie depends on the interactions between the two, and it's in those moments that it seems to succeed. The twist at the end was good, and definitely surprising, but there still was some (or a lot) left to the imagination. Leaving this movie, it was hard to be completely satisfied because it's hard to be sure if everything was really resolved. This movie was pretty good but with its cast and direction it could have been much better and should have aimed much higher.

Review title: Cruise and Foxx in top form!
Review_body: Collateral is an interesting, exciting and suspenseful movie that is well acted and centered on a story that builds throughout the movie. Tom Cruise, Jamie Foxx and Jada Pinkett Smith all do an excellent job of bringing their characters to life. Cruise is first rate as Vincent, the hit man, who is in pursuit of completing his agenda regardless of obstacles or circumstances. In fact, he does such a good job, you tend to forget you are watching Tom Cruise acting out a role. He is more than believable as the bad guy. Jamie Foxx also does a great job as Max the cab driver who happened to be in the wrong place at the wrong time. His chemistry with Cruise and Pinkett Smith is excellent. He is a real joy and almost steals the movie from his much more famous co-star. While on screen much less, Jada Pinkett Smith delivers a believable performance as the taxi cab passenger who becomes more involved in the story of this movie than she might have really liked. To say more would give away some of the thunder of the movie. This is one you do not want to know too much about before viewing.Check out the DVD when you get a chance, you won't regret it!

Review title: An exciting film with a ludicrous plot
Review_body: First off I have to admit that I find it difficult to take Tom Cruise seriously in any role which requires the distillation of menace. He is too lightweight to give much credibility to the role of a professional hit man. Jamie Foxx, on the other hand, is a credible innocent victim caught up in a nightmare taxi ride. The story is exciting enough but the circumstances around the involvement of Foxx in the night's horrors is too ludicrous for words. That a professional hit man would deposit his first victim on the roof of the cab he is using to carry out his contract is so stupid as to completely discredit the remainder of the movie. That such a man would use an innocent dupe to carry him around is feasible but that said dupe would be fully conversant with the man's murderous schedule is not. I really cannot understand the high ratings given to the movie for the script might have done justice to a fifth grade essay competition but little more. Sorry to say it but both Cruise and Foxx have done better things.

Review title: I'd give this one a miss
Review_body: Nice premise but this film is so disappointing it's hard to even know where to start. The first twenty minutes are actually pretty good but from then on it just gets worse and worse until, eventually, it descends into nonsense. Cruise's ruthless and anonymous assassin suddenly becomes sloppy and very public when it fits in with the writer's wayward plot. He even takes time out from his hectic evening schedule to make a caring hospital visit. To say certain bits are unrealistic is an understatement. As a kid I probably would have really enjoyed this film, what with all the action. As an adult I just see the plot holes and unrealistic bits as plain frustrating. And the 15 minute 'wonder who's going to win' climax was always going to be predictable. Waste of time. Although Cruise was still very good.

Review title: Gifted filmmaker strikes gold yet again
Review_body: Collateral was one of the big noise blockbusters I missed last year, so I lapped up the opportunity to attend a matinée screening. My comments shall briefly echo the majority of those before me, in singing the praises of this joyously crafted masterclass in post-noir cinema. Michael Mann, he of "Miami Vice" origin, has accumulated quite a resume of taut, introspective thrillers in the 90's with "The Last of the Mohicans", "The Insider", and the seminal "Heat" as his defining moments. Collateral in many ways bears much resemblance to this latter work, with Mann's sweeping, neon-drenched cinematography again purporting the vibrancy and mythical qualities of Los Angeles whilst surrounding an unconventionally explored tale of good vs evil, and the increasingly blurred line on which they tread. Certain elements of its final confrontation also recall Heat's outstanding Pacino-DeNiro face-off finale, although this time the audience has more idea who they're rooting for.As hit-man Vincent, Tom Cruise shows off a perfectly satisfactory yet previously unexplored flair for villainy - he is ruthless, dangerous, and darkly reflective of the nature of his work. His low-key intensity carries a near-perfect contrast and sizzling chemistry with the psychological frailties of his co-star, a certain Jamie Foxx. Already launched into the critical stratosphere for his performance in Ray - for which he will in all likelihood receive the Oscar tomorrow night - here Foxx is given the opportunity to create his own character, and does he ever. He perfectly conveys the twitchy, downtrodden confusion of a man at breaking point from failure to follow his idle dreams, suddenly thrust into a violent world of seemingly random murders and dubiously moral retribution. Personally, I'd enjoy seeing him receive the supporting actor Oscar for this and allowing Leo DiCaprio best actor for The Aviator (a scenario currently hanging by a mere thread of possibility).By now you most likely know all about the plot of ruthless hit-man commandeering taxi-cab across big city, but it's the sheer intricacies of the screenplay and direction itself which seemed to hit me with shattering impact. The entire opening sequence with Foxx and Jada Pinkett Smith, apart from its gentle romantics, was a pitch-perfect beginning to the film in allowing the density and tragedy of Foxx's character to be unearthed to the viewer, before the brutality of Cruise suddenly hurtles into his world. My personal favourite, though, would be towards the middle of the film, immediately following a bickering section between the uneasy acquaintances as they stop at traffic lights, and an Alsatian wanders across the road. It turns to face them briefly, its eyes caught in the cab's headlights, and trots off again. Everything about this brief moment, the camera slowing down, the way Foxx and Cruise both stare at the animal, is perfectly setup, and provides one of the most gently reflective moments in the whole film.Mann, like Tony Scott, is one of a select few distinguished Hollywood directors who can adapt to contemporary settings and styles without making them seem obnoxiously exclusive for the 'short attention span' youth audience. He pulls off an LA nightclub setting with panache and flair, without cynically layering it in multiple split-second camera angles and excessively intrusive music so common in modern action blockbusters. Similarly, he retains his trademark tension throughout, with even his dialogue-focused sections (notably a superlative conversation about Miles Davis) brimming with the anything-could-happen factor that remains prevalent for the full two hours. Occasionally, this factor seems TOO prevalent - when Cruise is shot in the face, and then stands up again almost immediately, I half-expected a glimmer of titanium skeleton to flash from underneath the bloody organic tissue. (Indeed, occasionally Cruise's performance recalls Robert Patrick as the menacing T-1000 cyborg in Terminator 2!) Despite this and the employment of various supposed genre clichés - the "pairing of white-black" old chestnut, the "happy ending" of sorts - the terse atmosphere leaves you too entranced to really consider such trivialities. People who moan about plot holes and over-suspension of disbelief should be ignored anyway. It's cinema.The film certainly serves what is expected of Mann, but it stands out amongst the increasing crowd of modern genre thrillers, taking pride in being as thoughtful as it is tense, as contemporary as it is classical, as violent as it is human, and as well acted as it is conceived. If its sporadic bleakness makes it occasionally difficult to watch, its tightness of structure as a narrative and the caliber of performance it extracts from its two leads more than compensate for such a discrepancy. Only The Bourne Supremacy has been anywhere near as impressive from last year, and that had its uneven moments. A discerning cinema-goer could do far worse than what is arguably the best of its kind from 2004.

Review title: I saw the film, and I'm pretty critical of it. (maybe spoilers)
Review_body: I was talking with a friend of mine just now, and we got on the subject of movies. He asked me if I'd seen anything recently, and I responded in the negative... but quickly had to correct myself; I'd nearly forgotten that I went to 'Collateral' last night... yeah, it's that memorable.What I do remember about that movie was that I greatly disliked it. It had its moments... like the bad guy getting shot by the person he totally didn't think had the guts to fire a gun. But that's not cliché at all.I'm still not sure why the whole 'wolves crossing the road' scene was thrown in there. Was it supposed to be a profound, mystical thing? It was lame and not at all clever -- a little like the rest of the film.The "twists" are much too predictable. I was able to call more than five lines of dialog before they were spoken, and I don't go to movies to think; that's just poor writing.Foxx's character was WAY too dynamic to make any sense. A polite, considerate, taxi driver who is ready to puke/faint in the presence of death becomes, in the span of a few hours, capable of talking down fully armed mobsters and of shooting a man in the face. Granted, there's a woman involved, so I can certainly see letting that slide a little... but then her involvement brings me to my next point.This movie relies WAY too much on totally absurd coincidences. I kept thinking to myself, "What in the heck?! What are the chances--!?" Overall, the actors weren't terrible, though their abilities should have been spent doing something else; the writing was rather lame, and as I said before, it just wasn't clever.If you'd like to watch a movie with a couple of gunfights, a bunch of things breaking, some folks dying, and a hit-man arguing philosophy with his cab driver, this is probably the flick for you. Enjoy.

Review title: lots of hits with a few misses....
Review_body: i have to say i really enjoyed this movie. from the get go, it really pulls you in. jamie foxx is truly a great actor, which he shows in this film. cruise delivers a solid performance as well. what is most interesting are the conversations between characters are effective at developing the personalities of the two. unfortunately, you become so attached to both the good and the bad guy that there is virtually no way this movie could end without leaving some viewers cold. the pace of the movie gets a little floaty somewhere in the middle and slows down for a bit, but it picks up again. even when the movie feels like it is moving slowly, it is still interesting. bottom line, good action, good suspense, good direction, and a few very humorous moments, but held back by kind of a sloppy mess of several different genres being thrown together. but since i was entertained and interested throughout by the deep and believable characters and dialogue, it deserves a solid 8.5/10.

Review title: Review, by a self-proclaimed movie snob
Review_body: So, as many of you may or may not know, Michael Mann is no stranger to great movie making. Although his resume includes "Ali" (a mediocre movie in my opinion), he has created such breathtaking masterpieces as "Heat," "The Insider," and of course my personal favorite among his work prior to "Collateral," "The Last of the Mohicans." This last movie was the first Micheal Mann Movie I ever saw. What a masterpiece of visual imagery. Many of you might be tempted to say that "Last of the Mohicans" offered nothing new. But watching the movie was like a drug, a feel-good ride that has offered me the same thrill over and over in subsequent viewings. Perhaps it is this effect that attracts me to Mann's work: A consistent promise of great things to come, a dreamlike perfection seldom attained in everyday life.As with any other Movie, I attempted to clear myself of any preconceived dispositions in lieu of a new work. Once in my chair, the first scenes play like a slowly spoon-feed meal laced with that bit of Mann's magic that pervades all of his work. Thirty minutes into the movie, and I have no clue where I am. Just that I am now in Los Angeles (the backdrop of the film). Slowly I am ever more engulfed in the carefully and delicately weaved story taking place before me. Soon, I forget that Jaime Foxx ever appeared on "In Living Color" or that Tom Cruise ever appeared in such movies as "Risky Business," "Top Gun," or "Minority Report." Instead, I see the characters for what they are: complicated and real.....amazingly real.The stream of little details written into the script plays well to the audience. We learn about more about the two main characters in two hours than many of us learn about our friends or colleagues in many weeks or months. And yet, it all seems plausible, as if somewhere, this all might actually be happening.All this, and one major shock. Jaime Foxx.....when did he become such a great actor. His portrayal of a man cornered, played out so believably and fluidly. I cant think of anyone else for his part. He really was Max! It was a Pacino-esque performance! Amazing! So good, that he severely overshadowed the ever-talented Cruise.My only complaint: near the ending.....the overall steam of the movie falls short temporarily, however it quickly picks up.Overall Rating: Best Movie so far this Year: 10 out of 10Awards and Praise are in Order

Man was this movie well shot. The use of the digital cameras really makes these action scenes appear grittier and real. From the opening scene you now that Mann is going to take you on a memorable ride of the urban L.A. landscape. Cruise displays his best performance ever as far as I'm concerned. I loved the decision to give him the gray hair and the stubble, It really separated him from his previous clean cut characters he has played. Jamie Foxx acts surprisingly well in this movie, I was impressed. Cruise's character is a slick, don't take crap from anyone bad ass in this movie. This is the best movie I've seen all summer, probably all year. Highly recommended

Most of the reviews cover it all.. the movie looked so promising with Tom Cruise and Jamie Foxx. An assassin using a taxi driver to transport him around the city over night whilst he kills his 5 chosen targets. Great potential!HOWEVER if "Vincent" was rated based from the rather known Hit-man game his rating would have been mass murderer or psychopath.. the worst rating! 1. Why use a taxi driver to drive you around the city? And if using a taxi driver, why not kill your victims silently and efficiently without the cabbie knowing.. would have made a better story. And WHY not just rent a car with a gps system, kill your victims and fly home safely at 6 AM?2. Oh the mistakes.. having your first victim fall out of his window and on top of the taxi? Really bro.. really? Killing two random guys 50 meters from pedestrians...sending your cabbie into a gangster meeting..not killing your taxi driver who throws away all your essential information.. driving around in the same car all night with a broken frontwindow, a corpse in the trunk and with a police warning already? Not risky? COMMON! And then the super idiotic nightclub scene.. not even gonna comment on that one. Wow, Just cringeworthy...3. Why the freak did he kill the lights before he tried to kill the attorney? Why is there only one guard on watch in a major lawyer HQ? Why did no one see the camera footage of a dead body and call 911? Omg.. 4. Why not just shoot the LAST target before talking to her and Jamie Foxx... the train scene..dreadful.Overall I enjoyed some parts of the movie but it turned out to be just to unrealistic, over the top with a TERRIBLE ending. Just terrible ending. The last 30 minutes I knew every step of the way and almost turned it off.Tom Cruise is the man but the movie could have been SO much better. 5/10

Review title: a film where everything is real and nothing can be foreseen
Review_body: It' a very well made movie, a sort of thriller with psychological implications (but not a psycho-thriller!). Although the principal characters are two, and we all already read or heard they acted both very well, the film seems to be a sort of choral movie, as it gives the right importance to every character. Just think about Javier Bardem acting in the role of the criminal who ordered the homicides, or Mark Ruffalo acting as the witty detective who is the only one to understand the situation. I didn't like very much the use of the steady-cam intermingled with more conventional filming. But it's only a personal point of view. Actually, it is pregnant of meaning. The changes between this kind of "real-tv" and conventional filming, as sudden and rapid as the changes between air filming and close shots, represent the intention to depict the characters from many different points of view: as being part of a big city, as little points over the face of the world, as main characters of an action scene, or in a more intimate way, as they talk, for example, into the taxi, or in the two nightclubs. A very good device is the startling homicide of the jazz player, exactly because the scene presents us a Vincent which resembles most the calm Vincent in the Taxi, who is a good listener, aware of the "facts of life". That's to say, although seen from different points of view, there is only one Vincent, and the Vincent in the taxi isn't less cruel than the killer. Another very interesting device is the continuous critic to "common sense" (in the worst exception). Anytime one of the two risks to sliver into banality (as in action as well as in his talkins), the other character destroys the impression by saying something startling.The result is a very realistic film, where everything is possible and nothing can be really foreseen.

For a "hit-man" movie I give this film a 10 out of 10, no doubt! Tom Cruise plays a great bad guy in whom is cool, so you tend to like him just as much as you hate him. The quick fight scenes are intense and highly entertaining. Of course "hit-man" movies don't have in-depth plots like a Gladiator epic, but one must know that when watching the movie. So you can't compare it to that. The problem with some of the reviews on people who didn't like the movie, usually makes comments on how it was to quick or the storyline wasn't really deep. Hmmm, considering its a hit-man movie, yes it would be rather quick, and considering its not some Lord of the Rings trilogy, I suppose the person is right, it isn't that "in-depth". Go into a movie expecting something good "WITHIN ITS GENRE". I mean, how can you compare Robin Hood Men in Tights with The Return of the King? Standing in its genre, I believe it is the best of the best! Tom Cruise rocks!! Enjoy!

Review title: Wow you finally made a good film.
Review_body: Dear Mr. Mann, Your name finally fits the bill. I am impressed that we actually see an actor instead of the usual Tom Cruise. Good Work, please keep it up. Damn I am actually really totally amazed that you got Tom Cruise to act. I always thought he was the same person in every film he ever touched. Hey Micheal i know your a high paid director but can you at least give medriving directions to a video store who does not have any of your movies?I will give you a thumbs up on "The Last of the Mohicans." But Miami Vice the Movie. Damn It is almost like I am voting for Hitler. Do us all a favor and retire while you still have a dominate name...........I do love Collateral though can you recommend me the mode you were in? Sincerely, A better director than you!!!!!!!! :[]

Felix thinks that Max is Vincent. When Max leaves the meeting with Felix, Felix tells his associate that if 'anything goes wrong, kill him.' Well, if Felix thinks that Max is Vincent, and Jada's character lives, then isn't Max doomed to be murdered by Felix? Vincent never got to finish his assignment. Felix thinks that Max is the hit man that's working for him, and Felix makes it very clear that if the job isn't done right, then Vincent will be killed. If Felix thinks that Max is Vincent, he'll go after Max. Therefore, Max now has the life expectancy of a housefly. So, no chance of a Collateral II. Beyond that, I personally thought this was one of the best movies of 2004. Tom Cruise doesn't normally play dark characters, and I thought Jamie Foxx had some really great lines (What? I don't know any Rwandans!) I also think the music helped a great deal in establishing that "up-all-night" atmosphere that Michael Mann was going for.

Review title: Hollywood has been searching for the "true" meaning of life to film it!
Review_body: For me "Collateral" is just an another movie which focuses on how meaningless and mostly trivial our lives, dreams, expectations and occupations are! It is not only this outline that it tries to display, but also it suggests considering nothing as valuable in real life. So all we see are only obsessions that has to be cared for and to be taken into account! In the film, it is inevitable to see how "Vincent" was obsessed with his job and being "successful" gives him the right to judge the life and underestimate it cruelly. On the other hand, we see "Max" as always struggling to keep his dreams as alive as possible not to disconnect with real life before he gets what he wants from it. Thus, for me, "Max" and "Vincent" are the very same person in the film in terms of understanding the life! They are just living at the different stages of the very same life style. What I criticize is that Hollywood always tries to divide this very same life style into as two different life styles to emphasize on the "right" one and to let us catch a glimpse over what the "wrong" one might bring in the end! Western social understanding has some contradictions in this sense, and in a way, it is implied between the scenes of such films!

Review title: This movie is terrible don't believe the morons who say it's good !!!
Review_body: This movie is awful. So many gaping plot holes and the ending is so cliché. First why would a lawyer randomly give out her number to a CAB DRIVER ? Why would a LAWYER have feelings towards a cab driver, he's obviously out of her league. And oh yeah what a coincidence that this is one of 5 people on the hit mans list. WHAT ARE THE ODDS!! For a "6 year assassin" Vincent is probably one of the worst hit men in any movies I have seen. Instead of killing people in a secret and in a quiet manner, he does it so everyone can hear and see him. For example, when he shoots the two thugs near a busy sidewalk no one apparently hears him but manage to hear the taxi honking ? Then during the club scene he kills so many people in front of a large crowd as if the police won't ask those witnesses what he looks like, Then for some bizarre reason Vincent starts to encourage Jaime Fox to talk to this girl and have moral conversations with him, Lastly, the ending was horrible and cliché. Instead of having a nice twist or different ending, the movie ends with a taxi driver with no gun skills or experience being able to hit a "highly trained assassin". Like come on this is so unbelievable. For the morons saying it's the best movie, they obviously don't take moves serious and have an IQ of a monkey. It wasn't even entertaining. Don't watch this movie. I wasted so much time and money on a lousy movie !!!!!!

I watched this movie and thought it was excellent very well made every bit of the movie was exciting and brilliant. Tom Cruise is a fantastic actor and there is no movie he makes where he will bore you also Jamie Foxx is great . i wish the movie was for abit longer though as it was so interesting to watch and it also has some very good music and songs in this movie which works well for it. The acting of every person in this was done brilliantly these actors really know how to act and it would be great if there was a second part to the film but i doubt it. If you are into thrillers that is done with style then this is the movie for you it is defnetly worth watching and also buying no regrets at all.and is defnetly in my DVD collection. i can watch this over again!

Review title: Character study packaged as a taut thriller
Review_body: Collateral is such a great thriller because it makes you care for its characters. You see the shyness and lack of initiative in Max's expressions and you know that these traits have plagued him his entire life. You see the loneliness in Vincent's eyes and you begin to wonder how he became the cold, sophisticated killer that he is.Mann develops his characters in subtle nuances. A brief three minute scene is all it takes to show how lethal Vincent is. An early conversation between Max and a passenger reveals everything about Max's character, while developing the passenger's personality as well.I have watched Collateral many times and while the action remains realistic and exciting, it is the characters and their transformation under the cold neon lights of LA that makes this movie refreshingly satisfying.9/10
The only thing I disliked about this movie was the ending. They could have gone along with Vincent's character in another movie. Like a sequel. Really entertaining since the beginning till the end.

Review title: An exploration of the man's solitude in the city
Review_body: "Collateral" is an experiment that proves that all man and woman live and die in a disconnected world where nobody knows nobody. Such a curious thing that it seems that we all live in a parallel world where you don't know the guy who's sitting next to your seat at the train or the one who is in front of you just across the street. He or she might be a dying wolf in the middle of this jungle we call city.The steady cam makes you feel your rolling alongside Max and Vincent, and shows you the lights and shadows of Los Angeles.Collateral, in my opinion, might be the best Tom Cruise performance.I invite you to take a ride on Jamie's cab across an L.A. night.

The main story and players are all over the box art and the other reviews, so I'll focus on the essence of what is good and bad about Collateral. Tom Cruise, Jamie Foxx, and to a lesser extent Mark Ruffalo, are the best parts about the film. Jada Pinkett Smith isn't as impressive, but she does an okay job as a sort of love interest for Foxx. What brings the movie down amounts to a slew of embarrassing production defects. During the mid 2000s, digital filmmaking was starting to gain more traction, and Collateral was one of the first big budget films to make use of the new technology. What might have looked groundbreaking at the time looks simultaneously dated and aimless now. There are way too many shots that are unfocused or jittery for seemingly no purpose, effectively taking attention away from the above average narrative. Another issue is the laughable choice in licensed tunes; the songs aren't necessarily bad on their own but don't match up with the tone of what is on screen. There are some character inconsistencies as well but I don't want to include spoilers here.In summary: If you focus solely on the lead actors performance and narrative, then Collateral will be an enjoyable thriller where Tom Cruise plays against type. If you prefer an engaging story that is propped up with cohesive production design, then there are better crime thrillers to see first, including ones from the same director.

If you have a lot of money it is wise to invest it in something secure and dependable. This is why it pays to cast Tom Cruise in any big budget production for despite his rise to stardom in a film called Risky Business Cruise has shown an unwavering consistency in his career that guarantees he is alway a safe bet when it comes to making a film bankable.Cruise you see always plays the same EXACTLY the same character by that dazzling grin and slight shortness of stature Cruise is invariably a brash self-confident charmer with a mere hint of vulnerability think can do salesmanship accompanied by just the tiniest scruple of doubt. Yet if performance never really changes there are occasionally films which exploit this by placing him in unusual positions and bringing out the cracks beneath his cocky all American surface films like Magnolia Eyes Wide Shut and now Michael Mann Collateral

Review title: Good direction, performances, and suspense. Weak ending..
Review_body: I believe that the scenes in Collateral were very well set up. The lighting, the angles, and the camera movement. I am also glad to see that seemingly raw digital video was used for filming. Although a bit distracting at times(because it's noticeably different than standard film or modified DV), it's something I'd like to see more of because of its' crisper image on screen.The direction and performances were also great. You really got to know the characters, and learn about them throughout the progression of the movie. Initially, I doubted Cruise's ability to portray "The Bad Guy", but he did so very well, making his role as 'Vincent' believable. Foxx also did a great job, showing his ability to portray serious roles, in contrast to his usual comedic jobs.The disappointment to me was the last 20 or 30 minutes of the film. As many reviewers have stated... It was cliché'd and almost ridiculous.It was a big let down to see an extremely experienced, sharp, collected, ruthless hit-man instantly turn into an obsessed, rampaging, sloppy madman. While at the same time, a clumsy, frightened daydreamer becomes a cool, collected ace.. all in an 8 hour span. Not to mention that he overcomes by blindly firing a weapon which 'just so happens' to inflict a fatal wound on Vincent, who at the time (although still keeping his shots in form) fails to realize that the steel doors he's aiming for may not allow the bullets to pass into his intended target.I personally would have much preferred for Vincent to have lived, whether or not he accomplished his final hit. (Seeing as the case the hits were intending to jumble, had for the most part, been effective) When they both ran out of shells, it should have stopped there, without further casualty, and ended up with Vincent walking off and disappearing, with Max left dumbfounded, but grateful for his own life (which would have been taken under any other circumstances according to comments earlier in the movie). The reason for this view is that throughout the movie, Vincent shows that he can be empathetic, and tries to understand Max's situation. This shows that Vincent is performing his job, and is probably a nicer guy off the clock. I'm not trying to excuse his status as a murderous hit-man, but show that he's someone who strives to be the best at what he does, just like Max is in regards to his cab driving job.

Review title: Tom Cruise: The Original John Wick
Review_body: The movie starts off relatively slow, but the moment Tom Cruise gets into Jamie Foxx's taxi is when the movie kicks off. The interactions between the two are a joy to watch. Even though Vincent (Tom Cruise) is a villain in this movie, He's just so charismatic that some part of me was rooting for him. Vincent is like John Wick before he existed. This movie may not be as fast paced as John Wick, but it's more intense in my opinion. I've never been the biggest fan of Jamie Foxx, but he played his role as Max, the taxi driver pretty well. A part of the movie I found to be unrealistic is that near the end, Max suddenly knows how to use and shoot guns pretty well. Overall though, I enjoyed the movie and would gladly watch it again in the future.

There were three separate instances in which I think we were supposed to see the trace of humanity still alive in Vincent's character. Here is where I saw his conscience showing through: 1. He buys flowers for Max's mother reasoning that she carried him for nine months. This was very inconsistent with Vincent's proclaimed nihilism.2. He felt that Max was indebted to him after he saved his life at the club fever. In the cab after the shootout he shows genuine frustration at the lack of thanks that Max gives him. Vincent shows a desire to be commended for doing something good.3. Vincent's death at the end of the movie is portrayed as being tragic instead of justified. His last words "do you think anyone will notice?" indicates that he would like his death to be a loss to someone. Despite whatever his reason may tell him, he still at some level wants a certain kind of human contact.I kinda had the feeling that the audience was supposed to pick up on the conscience that Vincent will never be rid of. so wha'd'ya'll think

Michael Mann's Collateral has a great deal of critical acclaim and hype behind it, so I was looking forward to watching it. But sadly, I was disappointed to find a very unremarkable thriller. The story really is as straightforward as you've heard: taxi driver meets hit-man, hit-man has five stops to make, and needs taxi driver to bring him to all five hit locations. The plot, I think, is the main reason why it was so hard for this film to work- it's just too linear. There are very few or no ways of pulling a plot twist, or changing the course of the plot. It was obvious Vincent would not be arrested with three hits to go etc. Compared to the best thrillers of the last ten years, Collateral appears even more average. It is not as violent as Reservoir Dogs, as complex as The Usual Suspects or as thought provoking as Fight Club. There is still some things to enjoy, however: the brilliant scene where Vincent confronts the muggers, and the nightclub shootout is good too. Foxx is fantastic as the cab driver Max and thoroughly deserved his Oscar nomination, while Cruise is also cold-hearted yet charismatic. If you like thrillers, give this a look, but don't expect anything too heavyweight.
I know this movie has been out forever but I just rewatched it again and can't atay quiet. The plot is riddled with holes. Just dumb. Horrible movie

I can't see why so many people seemed to love this movie. I watched it last night and I would call it mediocre at best. The entire story is cliché and I liked the hit-man with a heart of gold character a lot better Jean Reno played it in The Professional. I can't take Jamie Foxx seriously as a leading man. Collateral works for several important reasons: the acting, soundtrack, directing, and story are all exceptional, without any major flaws. Reading the comments on this film from other viewers is almost amusing, because the film is almost too subtle for many people to fully appreciate. Here's why: SPOILERSTo fully understand Collateral, it's helpful to watch the film several times, and keep in mind the "bigger picture" of the story. If you don't pay close attention, then you're not going to understand why the events in the movie transpire as they do.The biggest complaint about the story is that Max, who has no experience with firearms, is somehow able to gun down a professional killer. But the true beauty of that scene is that not only does it make perfect sense, the outcome is almost inevitable. Not because the story dictates it, but because the mathematics of the people and environment add up to Vincent's death. Here's the breakdown of the scene: Car crashes, Vincent runs off without his pistol (H&K .40 S&W), but with a spare magazine still on his belt. Vincent then kills the guard and steals the guard's Smith & Wesson-which is in a different caliber. He undoubtedly shoots the guard at least three or four times.Max throws down the police officer, and picks up Vincent's gun from the wreckage. He shoots the door twice to get in. Then he shoots Vincent once in the neck. Vincent fires five rounds at the fleeing Max (so he's already used eight or nine rounds).In all likelihood suffering from blood loss, Vincent trades shots in the subway with Max: Vincent fires three shots, Max fires somewhere between 6 and 10. Except that Vincent is a trained marksman, and is aiming directly at Max by instinct. Max, on the other hand, wildly pulls the trigger, throwing his shots all over. Vincent's three shots all impact the metal frame of the door, and stop without going all the way through. One of Max's lucky shots goes through the window and hits Vincent in the side. At that point both run out of ammo: while Vincent has spare magazines, they won't fit in the gun he's holding. Already badly injured, Vincent realizes he's mortally wounded, and sits down to die.That's only one example of how precisely thought-out and planned the film is. The laws of physics are never broken. Nor are the laws of reason: every action has a motive. By the end of the film, both men have intellectually demolished each other. The only thing left for Vincent is to complete the job, it is the very core of his existence. For Max, saving Annie is also saving himself-his morals, and his future. Neither of them desires to kill the other: Vincent warns Max by saying "I do this for a living" while Max shows stunned regret by telling the dying Vincent that they're almost to the next station, and medical care. At the heart of the film is the existential question of why we're here on this earth, and what it means for us. Neither Vincent nor Max seem to really have an answer to that question, and in comparison Vincent's nihilism and Max's working values both seem equal failures. It's clear in the jazz club scene that Vincent regrets the necessity of killing the musician. And it's clear after the Fever shootout that Vincent is seriously uncertain of his own reasons for being from his facial expressions and defensive tone. At the same time, Max is undergoing a transformation of his own, beginning with his confrontation with Felix, he begins to finally assert himself. Arguing with Vincent, crashing the cab, assaulting a police officer, and finally shooting at Vincent, he truly lets go and approaches Vincent's state of free-flowing improvisation. Only by letting himself act freely does Max become a whole person. The tragedy is that Vincent couldn't. Since one of the foundations of the film is the influence of chance in everyday life, one must wonder what could have been...END SPOILERS There's much more to be said about this film, multiple perspectives to approach it from, many more subtle hints buried in the material that I'd like to explain. But regardless, Collateral is a masterpiece of recent cinema, and fully deserves to be ranked with other classics of drama.

Review title: Great crime drama! Michael Mann does it again!
Review_body: Michael Mann is great at crime dramas. I have loved many of his projects including...Miami Vice, Heat, and Collateral. I have seen other work from Michael Mann but these were/are my favorite. I was so pleased to see these actors assembled-- each playing great parts and getting them together so well on screen.Tom Cruise is impressive-- easily filling and succeeding in roles that might have gone to other greats in their time, such as Paul Newman, Al Pacino, Steve McQueen, Robert DeNiro, Robert Duvall, or Gene Hackman. Tom Cruise has definitely got more gift than some may give him credit for, including myself.Jamie Foxx was terrific! I haven't seen him in too many films, but I'll definitely be looking closer now.Jada Pinkett Smith really has something special about her! Despite her part being smaller in this film, she added so much-- definitely the right person for the role.I completely engaged in this story-- it was an awesome ride!

Only one of too many unbelievable facts: if so, I prefer going to see Spider Man.

Collateral is Mann's best work to date in my opinion, even eclipsing Heat. The film has just the right feel to it throughout with fantastic cinematography and use of HD digital. The filming style is so dead on perfect for the deep, somber feel this film has. The images noticeably sharp and crisp, especially in expertly shot club shootout scene, and in the Taxi.Also, excellent work by Jamie Foxx turning in a top shelf performance and displaying phenomenal range.*SPOILERS*The story is gripping and thought provoking. The two main characters have inverse flaws. Vincent has lost all emotional elements a full human being has. He is cold and calculated, never getting anxious or out of place. He is essentially a "terminator", which is exactly what he looks like when he comes crawling out of the crashed taxi unphased, and moves on to complete his mission like a machine. Vincent takes the viewpoint of his work is no less inhuman as everyone else. Max has the inverse, he is too soft and timid to take any risks. He might be the best cab driver in LA, but is clearly underachieving. Max lacks the confidence to match his intelligence. He visits his sick mother every night talking about his dreams, and has his days free for 12 years to complete his business plan. Both men touch on the fact that they were raised differently creating their respective flaws. This theme runs throughout the film of environmental factors are the primary contribution to one's persona. Mann also brings many different ethnicities into play illustrating this environmental theme. In the fantastic ending, Max is forced into a position of protecting Annie out of moral obligation, and ends up killing Vincent. Vincent's actions have pressed Max to use confidence, and force him to take action. He never would have called Annie, and never would have changed his life. Vincent in the end chose not to pick up that clip of bullets. He became more than a "terminator" because of Max. We actually feel sorry for Vincent as he asks "Do you think anyone will notice?" This film combines sociological and philosophical elements with a gripping and interesting action/drama. This kind of film is always hard to pull off, but Collateral clicks on all cylinders. 8/10

Review title: A film I like with Tom Cruise in it!
Review_body: I fell in love with Michael Mann's perspective of urban architecture and how it's transferred to film after watching 'Heat'. This film sets you in a great city(L.A.) with great music(Audio Sound plus more)with all the night creatures. Jamie Foxx is amazing and Tom Cruise's Supporting Role is spectacular right to the point. It's as if the role for Tom Cruise was made for him(not at center stage). I have watched this film at least 4 times and sit in awe even though I know the outcome. Mann seems to get the exact angles and creates the urban lighting that puts you right at the scene. I haven't seen 'Miami Vice' yet, but I fully endorse Michael Mann's abilities as a film director and suggest this film as a keeper for any movie collection. It may not be the best Mann film, but surely ranks with 'The Last of the Mohicans' for detail and stylized violence that keeps you in disbelief that these events follow an average guy working a honest living. The only negative point I found was the ending. Foxx's character did more than he was probably capable of, and Cruise's character slipped up when he had did greatness throughout the film. I enjoyed the concept of the storyline that many films lack. Hollywood should try making stories into films rather than finding ways to dazzle us with special effects and amazing computer graphics. Well done Michael Mann!

Review title: Unbelievable - Truly talented acting combines with stunning Direction
Review_body: I have always felt that with things such as ratings, one should save 9 and 10's for truly timeless movies that may redefine your view on films in general. But as strange as it sounds to say, I can find nothing wrong with the masterpiece that is Collateral.This film noir is unbelievably subtle yet completely compelling. It proves to all that a 'good' movie doesn't require a huge budget, because as proved here you can't put a price on talent.Tom Cruise leads this on its otherwise limp feet. Never have I seen such a fascinating character build than Tom's Vincent. I say build because that is quite simply what it is. What Tom shows us is that no human is completely impenetrable, no matter how well trained. We see this in Vincent by the calculated coolness and mathematical killing that he has programmed himself to do which yet falters in a few situations during the film: the killing of the Jazz musician and the occasional fletching look after he has killed him. Vincents love of Jazz makes him realise what he is doing, but only for the fletching moment which is then quickly thrown out in his pursuit for the remainder of his targets. I know see Tom Cruise as one of the most talented actors I have ever seen.Yet Jamie Foxx's role must never be underestimated, as he proves the equal to Cruise, both in character and in acting ability. His step away from comic acting has been a successful one, as he plays the lonely and collective cab driver Max.The relationship between the two characters is the driving force of the entire movie. The wariness of each other which soon grows and develops as these two characters create a bond that the most important one of both of their life.Whilst the ending has been criticised for its predictability, there is no other real conclusion possible as one of these two men must fall. But frankly, I believe that this can be happily over looked, as the rest of the plot and the pairs relationship has enough twists and turns to satisfy.And to be honest, some moments of this movie are grippingly tense, such as the library cat-and-mouse, the dramatic and sudden car crash and the dependency during and after the night club scene.And as much as Max and Vincent are characters in this movie, the third main character in this movie is the city of LA. Never has a place been so unnervingly portrayed through someones eyes, in this case Mann's. The pallet of colours and locations are vital to the greatness of this film, and can not be overlooked. Small touches like the coyotes (can't spell it, sorry!) add a touch to this movie that parallels some of Vincents views of mankind: the selfishness, the insignificance, the loneliness etc.Frankly I could go on about this movie forever, so simply do yourself a favour, whether you are a fan of a brilliantly executed film showing someones view on mankind and life or simply love a great thriller, go and see the masterpiece that is Collateral.

I really enjoy TC's movies but I'm not necessarily a fan of him in particular. He is a great actor, I know that, but he hasn't been as credible to me as who he's playing more than in the role of Vincent. He straddles that line between cold hearted and charismatic villain. Jaime Fox nailed his role so good too. I can see it in his face, Max didn't know whether to admire Vincent or hate him. Just like we, the audience, did not either. It's 2021, right now and I can't see a clip referenced of this movie or even hear it be mentioned without getting that "Damn that was Such a good movie, Now i feel like watching it!" feeling.

**Scattered spoilers** for a scattered movie here on out.In the beginning you experience the life of the taxi driver (Foxx), cleaning his car, driving in the city, picking up people, taking a break to eat. All-in-all not too surprising.One of the fairs he picks up just happens to be a pretty woman (lawyer) that will later turn out to be the final victim. We get to see the entire cab ride of the pretty woman and the taxi driver, along with their conversation and his funny remarks which finally lands him her business card. This is important because he needs a number to phone to warn her that Cruise is coming to kill her.Back to the beginning. So after Cruise shoots his first victim (on the 4th floor), he crashes out the window and onto the taxi, oops. Cruise has to hide the body so he gets the help of the taxi driver to put the body in the trunk. The question is, assuming someone wouldn't see a body crashing out a window, assuming the taxi driver would really help, why didn't he take a cheap shot at Cruise?Then we ride to a penthouse. Then we ride to a Jazz bar. And midway through the movie we visit his mom in the hospital, which I guess is supposed to be the collateral. Cruise and Foxx are apparently always side-by-side, which makes one wonder if there was no opportunity for Foxx to sucker punch Cruise. Next we ride to a club called Fever.The "Fever" Club scene was probably the worst. From the time the first bullet is fired, 5 minutes later people are still running back-and-forth on the same dance floor, and the guy who is on Cruise's list is still sitting at his table waiting to be shot.Cliché list-getting stopped by cops who get another call to go somewhere else-throwing a garbage can to break a window but it doesn't break-last bullet cliché (where both people run out of bullets and are face-to-face)-invincible attacker (Cruise is shot but gets up and keeps going)-crashing the taxi to escapeIs he a smart guy or a dumb guy? It is really hard to connect with the taxi driver at an emotional level because his character kept switching between being portrayed as stupid (deserving of sympathy) and being portrayed at the over qualified taxi driver who can think his way out of any situation.The problem with this movie is that in each situation there were a million different ways it could've went, but in each situation the director always took the least probably to really occur. Thus, putting everything together in this fashion makes for a very unbelievable movie and leaves the audience in a state of boredom. 5 / 10

Better than Heat?If i say that i'm sure that 90% of the IMDb members will label me as insane or just stupid.But i will say it...In my opinion...''Collateral'' is better than ''Heat''!Here!I said it.Before you go to another comment or movie,let me tell you why I think that way. First,''Collateral'' is not just action-drama-thriller movie.''Collateral'' examines the people in the big city.It is FOR the people of the big city. Vincent says:''17 million people. This is got to be the fifth biggest economy in the world and nobody knows each other''.And this is not so unusual.I mean,look at the main characters.Max is just ordinary man,not a super cool taxi-driver,not a former CIA special agent,not ANYTHING special.Max is just one man with hopes.He got a island picture,and he just dreams when he wants to relax or just to get out from LA.He want to make a limo-company.He got dreams for the future...We all have!And he is just a man,who is in the wrong time,in the wrong place. Vincent is contract killer.Well,it's not the typical contract killer we've seen in movies like ''Jackal'' or ''Bourne Ultimatum''.He got philosophy.He got life.And he is a professional.Vincent just uses this for living.Like the butcher.The butcher kills animals for money.He take lives.Vincent makes the same.He didn't know the people he got to kill,but he don't want to know them.And he hates LA,he hates the big cities.The example...When Max is tied to the cab and he calls for help,nobody even notice him.Nobody,except the bandits.They use Max's position to rob him.Big City. Second,the actors.Well,i have to say that all the actors(From Mark Rufallo and Jada Pinkett Smith to Jamie Foxx and Tom Crusie) act at least very,very well.I mean,there is no bigger and small roles.That is the idea of the movies.Everybody are small in the big city and not only there.I think Tom Cruise makes his best performance since ''Born on 4th of July''.He is just charming in this so unusual role for him.Jamie Foxx plays excellent,he completely deserves his ''Oscar'' nomination.Smith and Rufallo also play good,not anything special,but good. And final,the directing.Michael Mann has a CLASS.I mean,for me only the scene with the wolf beats everything in ''Heat''.That's not only-the first scene,the last scene(which also is just great),the shootout when Vincent gets killed.And many more... Just watch the movie and try to understand it.

Collateral Starring-Tom Cruise, Jamie Foxx w/Jada Pinkett Smith, Mark Ruffalo, Peter Berg & Bruce Mcgill Directed by Micheal Mann Rated R for Violence & Language As the Film opens we are introduced to the films main character, no it's not the silver haired Cruise as "Vincent" or even the Oscar Nominated Foxx as "Max". The main character of Micheal Mann's newest picture is Lala land (Los Angeles). So much effort is put into rendering LA's nighttime beauty that it's almost a shame that this movie turns into a glorified chase thriller. The Films pace and mood are excellent until the "Feds" get involved. At this point it seems that Hollywood takes over and the underbelly of LA is forgotten. Up until Max walks into a Mexican cowboy bar the film almost seems plausible. From this scene on the movies storytelling and tension give way to corny lines (by the cops and feds alike), a car crash, and a terrible climax on the subway. I enjoyed Collateral's cinematography it echoes Mann's other work such as Heat and the Insider. Dion Beebe (Chicago) and Paul Cameron (Man on Fire) split the Director of photography role. Even though both DOP's did not work on any previous Mann films, they used their combined efforts to turn out a visually stunning piece that kept the same dichotomy of grainy film noir and ultra crisp pop art that is featured in other works of Mann. The almost Cain and Able comparisment between the movies stars works well, especially when both characters visit Max's mother in the hospital. This is further played out in the films climax. We never truly understand why Vincent is how he is, but we do know that he shares an almost brotherly love for Max. One which he has probably never felt before. *** out of *****
