In the movie Collateral there are many twists and turns like you would see in your typical thriller. Collateral however combines 2 types of movies in one. It is an action packed thriller. It stars Tom Cruise as the hit man Vincent, Jaime Fox as Max the taxi driver, and Jada Pinkett Smith as Annie the district attorney. This film is about a taxi driver Max who drives Annie to her office and during the trip she tells Max about a case she is working on. After dropping her off he picks up another fare, Vincent. Vincent is a hit man using Max to transport him around Los Angeles to do his contract hits in one night. When Vincent first approached Max's cab they almost didn't even hook up. Everyone in the audience knew something wasn't right with Vincent but they didn't know what. Unfortunately for Max he didn't see it coming in the beginning, however he should have suspected something when Vincent wanted him to drive him to his various business appointments and wait for him. After Max told Vincent he wasn't allowed to wait for fares Vincent pulled out a stack of $100 dollar bills and enticed him to drive him around for $600. This is when Max should have known something wasn't right but money can make people do what they ordinarily wouldn't do. Everything went downhill from here for Max. That first stop changed the rest of his night. As you watch the film Max's night will come full circle.The director (Michael Mann) did a great job in the beginning of the film to demonstrate the upcoming suspense but you weren't sure what was coming. He showed Vincent and another man walking through different parts of an airport. In these scenes all the people around them were blurred and the voices were muffled as to show that they 2 were destined to cross paths. They bumped into each other and one dropped his brief case while the other set his down to apologize then they each picked up the others case. This scene was very well done. It is much better than one sitting on a bench reading a magazine or something and then the other sitting down next to him and then one leaving and picking up the others case. Basically I'm saying it wasn't predictable. Looking at the film as a whole this was a great way to start the film. This film was a very entertaining action packed suspense thriller and I thoroughly enjoyed it. The editing for the most part was superb, however I did find a couple of areas that either could have been done differently or better. First some (not all) of the taxi scenes were unrealistic. The viewer knew which taxi window scenes were real and which ones were movies playing in the window. There weren't many but in my opinion with today's technology there should not be any scenes that look like a movie in the background window. Next in the end of the movie when Max and Annie are fleeing Vincent in the subway they go to the lower level platform and hide out of the sight of Vincent. As Vincent comes down the escalators he stops at the platform above the lower platform as 2 trains come into the station, one on the lower platform and one on the level he is on. He is trying to determine which train he thinks they're on. The director or editor didn't show Vincent going down or even attempting to go down to the lower platform they just showed him getting on the same train as Max and Anne. Like I said earlier, this is a great entertaining thriller with just a couple mistakes on the editing side of things. Maybe I am a bit too anal.

Review title: Great writing, great acting, great directing...
Review_body: I saw an early screening of COLLATERAL and was very impressed. I really liked Michael Mann's choice of using hi-def digital film and loved his use of many parts of LA to convey how gritty this character-driven thriller/action movie is. Jamie Foxx has definitely proven that he has a lot of range and I cannot wait to see him in the movie RAY (where he plays Ray Charles). Tom Cruise did an excellent job as the villain (I enjoyed this villain much more than his portrayal of Lestat in INTERVIEW WITH A VAMPIRE). There is a ton of witty dialogue (thanks to Stuart Beattie's great script) with all characters, but especially between Jamie Foxx and Tom Cruise. For those looking for action, there are some great "shoot 'em up" scenes, but what really stood out was how strong each character is written. SPIDERMAN 2 proved to be a success because it wasn't so much genre-driven as it was character-driven, and I think the same applies to COLLATERAL.

How would it feel to have to drive a mile in Max's shoes? As I watched this movie I kept asking myself what I would have done if I was in Max's (Jamie Foxx) position. Vincent (Tom Cruise), a contract killer, forced Max to drive him around Los Angeles while he murdered people. Ultimately Max had two choices, to either drive the cab for Vincent and be a part of his murders or refuse to drive which would most likely result in his own death. If Max refused, wouldn't Vincent have just gotten another cab? Why didn't Vincent just get another cab driver? These questions filled my mind as the movie progressed. At the climax of the story, Max got away from Vincent but then found out that Vincent's next victim was his earlier passenger, Annie (Jada Smith). Max gave up his freedom and safety and decided to try and rescue her. Through pure selfless ambition, Max made every attempt to save Annie's life. What causes somebody to give up their luxuries or freedoms to help someone in need? Eventually Max saves Annie's life and rids the world of another killer. Max killed a person in order to save a life. Is Max's decision to kill Vincent justified? It is easy to say that he made the right decision because he saved the innocent person, Annie and took away an evil, Vincent. But doesn't this make Max ultimately wrong by taking somebody else's life? I recommend this movie to anyone who enjoys a thriller and a chance to focus on human responsibility and morality. Feel free to post back with comments or questions.

Excellent character development, pacing, and photography have become the hallmarks of a Mann movie. I had eagerly anticipated this movie for months.My only regret was that I knew too much about it before I saw it. It would have been soooooo delicious to have experienced it without thinking "oh this is where such and such from the previews is about to happen."One other aspect that Mann brings to his filmography of action sequences is the sense of 'witnessing' the event. His camera angles, timing, and audio effects combine to provide the ideal experience of an eyewitness.If you have not done so, go back and watch his movies with a particular eye towards the realism he brings to 'your experience'. He is right there with masters... Kubrick, Hitchcock, and Scorsese.

Fully agree with all the comments; but not only direction, acting and lightning are great, also the chosen music. Simply worth a soundtrack-CD. A fine mix of Latin, Pop, Lounge, Jazz and even classical motives, accompany the scenes. In most comments on films the chosen music is underrated. Imagine this film without the accompany of music. Most of the specific moods, tense and even sometimes relaxation will be missed and what than should rest is a normal thriller pumped full off classical bombary music. This chosen mix adds simply a most forgotten but necessary ingredient (like in most recipe's) a fine smoothing oil.

Review title: One of the best motion pictures in 2004
Review_body: Collateral [2004] ; Might contain a few slight /SPOILERS/.In the beginning of this movie, we can perfectly see how Max the taxi driver (Foxx) lives in a total routine and we are shown which dedication he puts into his job despite the routine. Soon, we meet a man called Vincent (Cruise) who is clearly referred to as a delicate but not an ordinary man, who has just arrived in the town and hires Max's taxi for the night.Foxx perfectly acts out the role of a casual man, who is frightened after finding out what Cruise's character really is up to. His character also "develops" into a more confident and braver man . Cruise also does a wonderful job as Vincent, showing us how cold-blooded and yet, so discrete a "hitman" can be. What I also liked about the acting is the way how Cruise's character is somewhat lesser than Foxx's, which is quite exceptional as Cruise is a tremendously more distinguished and popular actor.The movie doesn't get boring even for a single minute, because no scene is left without action or interesting dialog for too long - Michael Mann is the man when it comes to not letting the audience get bored.To my mind, this motion picture is the best of 2004 so far. 10/10 .

Take the simplest of stories, say, two guys meeting, at night, in a taxicab, in Los Angeles, and turn this into, not just a mesmerizing visual experience but a poignant unselfpitying portrayal of the metaphysics of alienation in the 21st century, and you have crafted the rarest of the rare, namely a cinematic masterpiece.Shot entirely at night (mostly with a Thomson Grass Valley's Viper FilmStation digital camera), _Collateral_ pulls the viewer into a dark world, lit as if from inside a black hole of lost dreams, murdered futures and raw fear without losing sight of the possibility for physics-defying change within the main characters of the story, the hit-man Vincent (Tom Cruise) and his accidental chauffeur for the night Max (Jamie Foxx). Each actor underplays his role, and it is via this quiet intensity that the film's director (Michael Mann) moves these two men out of themselves and, however unwittingly, into each other's lives, not unlike the way Al Pacino and Russell Crowe had done in Mr. Mann's equally disquieting previous film, _The Insider_.Like its predecessor, _Collateral_, too, makes trust and betrayal as palpable (and as explosive) as guns and bullets, and also (again like its predecessor), this film makes you (the viewer) actual care about individuals whom you would most likely in your real life choose to avoid at all costs. In so doing, this film makes the mere act of living nay, of MAKING a living, an exercise of deepest courage and direst necessity. And it makes us see, through a glass darkly, that every word is a confession, every act a benediction, and every encounter a transfiguration of good and evil, right and wrong, life and death.

Tense, humorous, violent and enjoyable. Interesting circle for Cruise to go from passionate love in a subway car in Risky Business to passionless hate in an another subway car scene. Seems long at times -- waiting for some sort of climax, which because of foreshadowing you'll know will get there, but when. Los Angeles looks great. Getting tired of car crashes where people just walk away (Bourne Supremacy as another example). Cruise did an adequate job of relaying emotions and shift in character through his eyes. Foxx was controlled for most of the film and did an excellent job of creating a plausible character in an borderline plausible circumstance,

This movie gets Michael Mann back to what he is best at; tight action sequences, beautifully shot with a strong simple script. I have never been the greatest Tom Cruise fan, but he delivers in this role as long as you can suspend your memory of cheesy grin lead roles of the past.I got right into it from the opening sequences of LA at night and things just got better. For me the bar scene is at least a match for the heist scene in Heat.If there was a criticism it would be that the film changes tone in the second half by giving way to more traditional Hollywood needs and therefore loses some of the edginess that is created in the first half.But don't let that put you off, this is a film that has something different and will appeal to a number of age groups on different levels.

Review title: Worst movie I've seen in a long time
Review_body: I don't understand how its rated 7.7 on IMDb and 4/5 starts on amazon.com for the DVD. It's so bad! The plot is entirely ridiculous, most of the movie is boring scenes with them talking in the cab. My favorite part was Vincent's mystical powers however. Like when he magically decided to go down the escalator instead of outside, and picking the right train to jump on to. It's also always a good idea to cut the power so you can't see anything, when you're trying to find the person you want to kill, yeah... The movie had some decent action scenes, the one in the club was probably the best scene in the whole movie. If not for anything but the old, played out track Paul Oakenfold - Ready, Steady, Go. Still a pretty good song though, in the movie its in some Asian language, for some reason.

Review title: Good, but a better ending offered...
Review_body: This movie was very entertaining. Great characters, good storyline, decent dialog - especially at the beginning to set up the movie - but the ending disappointed. Why does the good, never-shot-a-gun-in-my-life, guy always beat the professional-killer bad guy? I doubt it! A more realistic ending would have been if "Vincent" defeats "Max", completes his mission, and then everything gets blamed on Max. It would also have led to a great sequel: Max, after a few years in jail (and learning a few new tricks), goes after Vincent after Vincent pulls off another series of hits. Come on Hollywood - give the audience a little bit of credit for SOME intelligence.

mann+cruise+dreamworks=perfectionperfection, in some sectors of the industry, is also known as box office hit. aka nothing-could-go-wrong. this movie took this equation and put it to work as perfectly as possible. so, did anything go wrong? let's see.Michael Mann is one of my favorite directors; his eye for human drama [notice the cut-to's to trembling hands and wide shots of multiple characters all absorbing one situation in silence] and his knack for character development [notice that his films, mostly, exceed 2 hours]are unparalleled. Collateral, though running just below 2 hours, is as Michael Mannish as it could be and more. Tom Cruise, playing a role that must've not been written for him, was really awesome. Jamie Foxx, unintentionally providing a touch of humor to Max's character, too, was awesome.yes, the story did not offer anything new, BUT the character development was just great - done in real Michael Mann fashion - that it made you think of other people and wonder how they, too, think and ultimately live their "regular" lives. just like how Mann pried into Crowe and Pacino to pour out Jeff Wygand's and Lowell Bergman's minds and souls in The Insider, he had Cruise and Foxx act out their characters to perfection. i've never seen Foxx deliver this kind of performance - far better than his stint as Willie Beamen in Any Given Sunday. could anyone have done any better as Max? probably not. could anyone have done any better as Vincent? probably. deniro + pacino, come to mind BUT we'd be missing Cruise's debut as a villain, which he did so in convincing fashion. in fact, it is just not convincing, it leaves you wanting Cruise to get even or, at least, go on two or more killing sprees just to show off his coldbloodedness!the cinematography was great; night-time LA, as well, was given character. Michael Mann was even able to squeeze in some of his signature nauseous arias as integral part of the drama [see The Insider, Heat + Ali].so, did anything go wrong? I need to watch it again. but my first viewing says it's negative of any major mishap. a slickly positive 9 out of 10.

Well the acting was excellent from both Cruise and Fox - they done their job, but can't say the same of the "deja vu" character Fox played. .. the ordinary guy, an intelligent cab driver with a typical way of life and a typical American dream(again), who's loving mother is in the hospital worrying about her son(again)and a charming customer Annie something like a main witness or prosecutor or kinda (I can't remember..)who's ready to reveal her problem(s) to a cab driver she met today for first time, and to give him her visit card(it's so romantic..(give me a brake!).What about an ordinary guy who becomes a tough guy when there is nowhere to retreat, if he wants to save the "girl of his dreams" and is forced to play the game hard when it is needed.. Sorry, but I've seen that many times in the Hollywood movies.. The thing I voted 9 for this movie is Cruise's character and only.

I recently went to see this movie at my local theater along with "Open Water" which also was a fairly good movie. Collateral is a fairly unconventional Action flick, I'm sure you have already read plot descriptions so I won't waste my time explaining it and go right to the acting, Cruise was outstanding as Vincent I ended up forgetting that it was Cruise on screen and, about 30 minutes into the movie i ended up rooting for him, the real surprise was Jamie Foxx who delivered a very believable performance as the captive cabbie.The only gripe I have with this movie is with the end it just left me wanting more. Overall It was my favorite movie of the summer.

About twenty minutes into the film, my girlfriend whispers to me what she thinks will happen. Low and behold, it unraveled into exactly what she said. That brings me to what I didn't like about this movie. Too predictable! I sat there waiting for a clever plot twist, something to keep me awake, but to no avail. Everything happened in typical crime drama/action film fashion. I wanted to see the end not because I was eager to see how it panned out, I wanted to see the end because I was tired of sitting through uninteresting dialog and shaky shots of the L.A. skyline.The slow burning hour or so eventually leads to something that you will want to sit up for, but if you've seen enough movies, you'll have this figured out and like most people who walked out of the theater with me, will leave, disappointed and expecting more.The action is played pretty well here. Standard fare, but well done. I enjoyed it for the most part.Overall, this isn't the breath of fresh air everyone is raving about. Go see it if you like Cruise and Foxx, because they play the parts well, and go see it if you like Mann's DV camera and awkward (at times)soundtrack, but don't see it because you are tired of the same old thing. 5/10 Go rent it when it comes out and buy some of that good pour over butter popcorn. Save your cash.ATHF

Collateral is a movie that you will enjoy no matter how many times you watch it. I am a cruise fan and was very impressed with his work in this movie, his comical yet serious role allowed you to develop an understandable relationship with him and the points discussed in this movie were excellent.In addition to the excellent acting in this movie there was good action as well, and it was displayed nicely. The only con i can find in this movie are the obscure camera angles that are used in the final product, the zoom in and out at points becomes irritating and at times annoying, but don't let that stop you from seeing a real great movie. also jamie foxx delivers an excellent performance

Review title: What a waste of 2 hours of my life!
Review_body: 2 hours of my life that I'll never get back. Not the worst film I've ever seen, but I can't even stretch to saying it was worth watching. Laughable, cheesy and cringy for a lot of the film...I imagine Jamie Foxx and Tom Cruise cringe at having been in it.

Plot : Hit-man (Cruise) pays taxi driver (Foxx) six - hundred dollars to drive around Los Angeles to pay a few...visits to certain people such as a witness to crime, and a attorney. When the driver realizes that his client is a cold - blooded killer, he is threatened and has no choice but to comply with the order of the hit-man. I will not reveal any spoilers.Opinion: A wonderful and pleasing movie from the start to the finish. Tom Cruise is truly becoming the modern day Al Pacino. Seeing Tom Cruise as the evil hit-man is a great new addition and improvement in his career and in this movie, it makes you want the bad guy, Tom Cruise, to be the victor of the plot. Jamie Foxx is a great supporting actor as his humor relaxes the environment and audience. This movie provides plenty of character depth especially in Foxx. The direction in this movie is superb and once again Director Micheal Mann (Heat, The Insider) proves he has great technique in his work. All in all, this movie is a 9/10. It is not too long, full of action, full of suspense, and full of plot. Go see it! By the way, I went in a screening with the press. Everyone applauded in the end.

Review title: Collateral was the most realistic movie I've ever seen!
Review_body: Collateral was the most realistic movie I've ever seen! Tom Cruise had to train with real guns and Jamie Foxx had to race with cars. They worked really hard and when I saw the movie I thought it showed. Tom Cruise was a killer actor and Jamie Foxx was so funny. Every body has got to go watch that movie. I saw it on the first day it came out. I saw the movie in citywalk right near universal studios. It really did seem like everybody in that movie worked hard to make it perfect and especially Tom Cruise and Jamie Foxx. It was a real experience that movie. I enjoyed every moment of it and so did my dad and my brother. If you like movies that seem realistic, funny, and entertaining, you have to see Collateral!

Finally a movie really worth watching this year. Certainly the DV Cam (digital) night shots can get a little distracting at times, but a compact script of a well-written closely knit story that is worth watching for its often clever quips and good performances by its two leads. Surprisingly, Tom Cruise plays both a sardonic and charming, sometimes philosophical, sociopath menacing Jamie Foxx's perpetual dreamer (a cab driver stuck in a temporary job, as he puts it, for the past 12 years). In addition, Mark Ruffalo, playing the "no one believes me when I tell them there is something strange going on here" detective showcases the calm demeanor you seem to find in all his roles. He does this expertly. About the only knock I have on this story is the casting of Jada Pinkett Smith. I think the role is so minor that it would be better to cast down, so as not to give anything away.Still she does an admirable job in yet another role for her where she is primarily furniture in scenes, as her character only serves to trump up the action. Then again there is just not enough room in the story to accommodate this.In a year fraught with box office titans simply trading on controversy, it is a pleasure to see a movie of modest scale that is poignant, real, and witty. Unfortunately, Mr. Mann's biggest gamble may prove to lose him recognition for his fine efforts. I applaud his desire to try and integrate digital and celluloid film, but like all pioneers he may be a little ahead of his time. Still, thank you, Mr. Mann. I enjoyed it. Can't wait for the next one.I certainly hope this movie has legs. If you ask me you should go see it.

Having read a great review in the LA Times about Collateral, I was excited to see this film. Stylistically it is well done and captures the dark "aloneness" of LA. The acting for the most part was also good and very convincing. Where the movie falls apart is in credibility and plausibility. There is nothing more aggravating than watching what would appear to be the makings of a great action/thriller fall apart because of ridiculous "Hollywood" plot conventions. The viewer is able to write off a few implausible quirks in the beginning of this film but by the end, it is just way over the top, especially with Tom Cruise's character jumping on the train at the end. Can't imagine what the director had in mind when he shot this particular scene. While this movie has some great "film noir" moments, in the end it is just another Hollywood "cheesefest".

Review title: Tom makes a better villain than romantic lead, but who was scared?
Review_body: Tom Cruise makes a better bad guy than a good guy. But Jamie Foxx's character didn't seem scared of Tom Cruise's character - so why should we be scared of the character either? Jada Pinkett Smith had a great role for any actress. Good scripted part, she gave a very strong performance, and there was no nudity or exploitive stuff! What a terrific role to play, what a great job she did. I felt the most 'transported' by the club scene - it just sucked me right into it. I felt it - the crowd's panic, the confusion, the randomness. The balance of the movie was far less effective in my opinion. Too bad, because I expected top drawer due to the buzz.

Very well written and suspenseful. The director out did himself this time I am sure. This is the first movie of his that I have watched. I will be checking to see what else is out that he has directed. The way he correlated the two people (Max and Vincent) to the point that Vincent seemingly liked Max...enough to take care of him in the strange situations that developed. Vincent even liked Max enough to the point that he felt lead to give him a few suggestions/resolutions to Max's life. I had to close my eyes numerous times on some of the scenes. They seemed so real. In the end though this was a strange way to begin and abruptly end what seemed to be a developing beautiful friendship between Max and Vincent (despite the fact they were forced into it). This is a must see movie.

If you are not a Tom Cruise fan, this is the movie for you. He plays a role only a mother could love, the heartless hit-man. However, he does it with style and pizzaz. This dude is sent to LA for an evening of take out - to take out five witnesses who are scheduled to testify in Federal court against a big time thug. Cruise ends up getting Jamie Foxx as his cabbie to chauffeur him to each whack job and soon ends up as a hostage driver. Jada Pinkett plays the assistant US attorney. The movie really starts rolling with the last hit. The action is fast and furious with hardly any down time. It's the best directed (Michael Mann of Miami Vice and Manhunter fame) movie I've seen this year.

Review title: Cruise and Foxx at their best! A film to remember
Review_body: First, let me start with director Michael Mann, which has made an excellent film, very well crafted story, shot beautifully, LA was the perfect set, those views over the city are just amazing! The story is very well told, soft ambiance, it takes you through a journey full of unexpected situations. The idea of being shot with digital camera fits perfectly, and gives it a kind of cool, soft and fierce ambiance. Tom Cruise is the king, along with Jamie Foxx, performed superbly! Tom Cruise, is cold, calm, and a unique sense of humour. Foxx has proved that he's not just comedy! It looks a real cab driver, funny, yet serious and pretty normal. Overall, one of the finest movies I've ever watched. Brilliant!! 10/10

Review title: Disappointing, Tom Cruise is still Tom Cruise
Review_body: Collateral has none of the suspense or thrills of 'The Insider' or 'Heat'. Mark Ruffallo is wasted, Tom Cruise looks like George Michael circa Faith. The taxi driver, Max, appears to have had Danny Glover (in Lethal Weapon) providing 'how to be cool around psycopaths' acting lessons. The love story is token, bowing to commercial pressures which youwould expect from Collateral Damage, but not from Mann. Moreover, Bacardi, purveyors of the funky fresh rum, appear to have sponsored the film outright, and their logo is in the second shot (and subsequent). Tom Cruise is not capable of carrying this off. He managed to play serious in Magnolia because (a) he was parodying himself, so excelled through irony, and (b) he wasn't the lead. Here he is still looking like he did in Top Gun, but with snow spray on his hair, and a Wham 4'oclock shadow. He is not helped by the dialogue either. Mann, like Tarentino, seems to have lost the knack for convincing small-talk among villains. In 'Heat' he humanises unusually brutal characters. In Collatoral, as critics have pointed out, there is an unusual amount of talk between the two leads. I'll steal from Pulp Fiction here; Just because Vincent is a character, doesn't mean he has character.Cruise is still wanting to be the charmer. So unlike Brad Pitt, who knowshow to unsettle us enough to ignore his beauty for a moment, Tom hangs onto his likability like a dog to a slab of meat. The 'sieze the day' and 'look at yourself man etc etc.' would be excusable if Vincent (Cruise) was exposed for the psychopath he is, a la Patrick Swayze in Donnie Darko, but instead Max the Tax sucks it all in and accepts his life is a failure. Odd, given he is the honest, hard- working stooge and Vincent is the ruthless psychopath. There is too much macho posturing, from the muscled cops and from Vincent's various penile extensions (PC tablets, cool Nokia phones and of course huge, huge guns), for his character to be truthfully presented. Instead we get an undercurrent of respect and sympathy for Vincent's effortless machismo and nihilism. This is dishonest, as Vincent's character is never developed enough to provide genuine reasons for our sympathy. So we are left with fetishistic appreciation of Cruise's martial arts skills, which he has picked up over the years in a series of awful action bonanzas, which I hope he returns to after this.

My most favorite movie ever. its the only movie that i think is worth a 10 on IMDb.The action in this movie is some of the most serious and realistic i have ever seen in a movie. i love LA at night time, its the most beautiful i have ever seen. I would recommend this to almost anyone that is into a good thriller and a movie with drama. The soundtrack in this movie really sets a certain mood that i haven't seen in any other movie. the movie can be really calm at moments and in some other moments it bursts into action. the characters are very well thought through. Michael Mann even went so deep into Tom cruises' character that he wrote a life story about his characters past even with pictures

This is a stylish movie that has some terrific cinematography. Angles, shadows, lights, pace and all the elements that make a terrific movie. Then there is the plot. The plot is more lost than a lost plot on an Ed Wood script in an Islamic Studio the day before Ramadan commences.OK. It might not be quite that bad, but there are holes in it that you could step through sideways. The Premise of a trained killer using one Taxi driver to run around L.A. for 5 hits in one night is the benchmark. If you can swallow that you needn't read further.Call me demanding, but what's the point in watching a mean -mutha-movie if the mean mutha is really a bad ass amateur who has a soft spot for congenial cab drivers. From the inconceivable rebellion by Maxx to the achingly dull mobile battery going flat, this film manages to do the opposite of it's intent and suspend belief.For a real slice of Tom Cruise as a bad ass (with the added bonus of depth) look no further than Paul Thomas Anderson's 'Magnolias'.

this is could have been a killer movie, tho..due to bad casting of one of the most important roles..only comes in as a decent movie. Jamie foxx never convinced me he was under any pressure at all during the whole movie..i mean..sure..he screams and yells some..but does it look like his actually sweating ?..nahhh..and that really drives the movie into the mud..since the whole nerve in the movie is about just that relationship. Tom cruise does an excellent job as a contract assassin. One more thing that nudged me was the police/fbi sidestory..now that feels like its been tossed together just because someone told mann it had to be in there..actually..it would have been so much better without it.In the end..this is a decent hangover Sunday flick that wont mess with ur head to much.

A " downloading movies is theft " add played before the feature, I ask is releasing this steaming pile of excrement, fraud? If so Michael Mann I demand my money back plus the time I suffered watching this drivel.Firstly Jamie Fox portrayal is flat, one-dimensional affair, Tom Cruise is Tom Cruise with a beard. The rest of the cast can be forgiven as they were earning a pay check.The D.P needs to be taken out & flogged, repeatedly. Erratic hand-held makes me want to puke. It isn't edgy it's crud that breaks the fourth wall.A taxi could drive through the holes in this plot. I could accept this if the pace cracked along, however the only thing cracking was the thin veneer of my sanity. Avoid this drivel, buy crack instead it's better for you. Michael Mann I await a check in the mail ....

I would recommend this movie for the cinematography alone. Shot all in digital, it has a very cool look to it. The helicopter shots, coupled with the in-car close ups make for a visually stunning picture. My favourite shot is when Cruise takes down two men with his gun, the camera stays on one shot and captures the action instead of cutting in with several fast shots. the effect is as if you were a first hand witness to the event. The music, specifically a song by audioslave, surprise you at first, but soon after become soothing and suit the mood very well. Jamie Foxx pulls a "Jim Carrey" and proves that he can be a serious dramatic actor. His performance is a memorable one. Cruise is his regular incredible self, playing a tremendously hateable villain. The story itself is very engaging and takes some very unexpected turns. I highly recommend this Film.

I watched this movie mostly because of very high rating and good reviews here in IMDb. So i expected quite a lot from that. Now, after watching it, i have calmed down. It wasn't any kind of historical masterpiece. Yes, Tom had some style as a bad guy indeed and there was some nice camera-work. But the script - it was boring and so predictable. Already after first killing, it was quite obvious, that Annie will be one of the targets. And in the end, Max will somehow kill Vincent. So i had to wait one hour, just to see, exactly how those things will happen. Such waiting, it is a sign of a bad thriller, isn't it?If this movie will get Oscar(s), i will be quite disappointed. And most certainly, Collateral is at least 1-1,5 points overrated here...

Review title: Watch it today and see how well it still holds up
Review_body: Please set aside any misgivings about Tom Cruise and his personal life, this film affirms his calibre as an actor and entertainer.When action movies started shifting to gritty in the mid 2000s, Mann was already there ahead of the pack. Collateral is very mindful action movie easy to miss in the sea of Bourne-alikes that quickly followed during this era.The format itself, set throughout the night time of LA gives the movie a sense of urgency as we follow Jamie Foxx's everyman cab driver through the streets and alleys.How good it is to see two actors here exploring a different side to their range; there's an ever present quiet menace in Cruise's depiction of Vincent that at times we are caught between rooting for him and recoiling from him; balanced by Foxx's hapless and helpless everyman cab driver, a far cry from the charismatic persona we are used to.Mann has wonderfully captured the LA night to give a sense of dread and danger throughout, down to the sound in the shout out scenes to give that flavour of realism.In some ways i feel this film has precursory elements to John Wick despite them being two different kinds of movies.Great movie making, rewatchable for the scenes, the backdrops, the acting, and Cruise's assassin.

Review title: Regarding NY skyline...I think it's an excellent film
Review_body: Someone wrote something about fabulous shot of NY skyline? The movie is in downtown LA. For someone that lived in LA, I think this movie really shows the rights spots. It hits up downtown and I can't help but laugh when nobody is on the metro rail. I think this really proves Jamie Foxx should be looked at as a legit actor and was a great lead-in to his performance in "Ray." As for Tom Cruise, he shows a good dark side. Most of his roles can be a bit goody goody, but I think he convincingly pulls off a hit-man. It sucks Mark Rufallo is shot, but I think it adds to the drama of the movie. Do see this movie if you haven't already, it comes out on DVD December 14.

Review title: Q: Are there two versions of Collateral? with movie review and comparison
Review_body: The Question: I just bought the Collateral DVD and saw a film that was very different from the one I saw in the theater. Reading the board comments causes me to ask: "Am I the only one, besides the other people in that theater on that day at that time, who saw that version of the movie?"The Review(s?): I thought both versions were really good, the DVD version seemed a little more tame but the acting and final message of both films were excellent. The characters, combat sequences, car wreck, emotional trauma, physical trauma, and cinematography all seemed very real (A Mann trademark). The more common of the Collateral movies that I just saw had a Hollywood feel to it, the music might have been something to improve on but it fit the story (The music from Bourne Identity was a plus). The nonDVD Collateral: had no soundtrack other than Max's cab radio, nothing to suggest what you should be feeling as you watched (although that was back on Aug 6th, my memory could be failing...); The fight sequences, actors (other than leading roles), were all different. Vincent was more of a casual killer and Max was less of a hero. The comparison between the two, nonDVD Collateral wins the high impact award while DVD Collateral wins the drama award. Each film seemed to have something useful to say. To compare it to Bourne Identity (have not seen Bourne Supremacy), sort of like the beginning where the girl feels she might have picked up a psycho in her car, multiply the effect by 10 or 20, throughout Collateral, and you have an idea of what the film feels like.As I watched, I attempted to fit what I saw in the theater to the DVD and could not do it, sort of a Twilight Zone effect...

Going into this movie i wasn't knowing what to expect but coming out of it i was not short changed as i unexpectedly enjoyed it. From the first hit to the last minute i was hooked with each of Cruises assignments getting harder and harder (expecially club fever) i was on the edge of my seat. A very moody but witty Tom Cruise as the bad guy was impressive none the less but i thought Jamie Foxx as the everyday cab driver stole the show as i was not expecting much from him but he delivered a hell of a performance. With each character tying into the plot delivered an enjoyable story which slowly unwound into an action packed finale....in short an enjoyable 2hrs well spent.

Tom Cruise put on a terrific performance. Some may say the ending is cliché, but Cruise is not. At points you think he'll say what you expect him to say, but his character has some tweaks that make him all the much better. Jamie Foxx put in some hard work as well, and showed that he is legit in all kinds of acting. Jada Pinkett Smith fit in nicely, and Michael Mann worked his cinematic magic. The soundtrack was well put together, and the use of bright lights and different colors is really appealing and desirable. It is a movie's movie. It's enjoyable, slow- moving but for the right reasons. The pace is perfect, and the story has some holes but that should not be misleading because the movie is all- around solid. Not all will say it was one of the best of the year, but as far as '04 goes, it is a movie that deserves a viewing.

I hadn't heard anything about this movie ahead of time, and honestly wasn't expecting much - possibly an excess of violence - so was quite pleased to find it was exceptionally well acted, had a compelling story, good character development, and interesting cinematography. I'm not a big Cruise fan, but was very impressed with his acting in this movie. Generally I've found his work to be shallow, or maybe it's the parts he is given to play. This was a fascinating character, and he did a fabulous job. I admit I kept hoping for some kind of change, some evolution of the character, but honestly it couldn't have happened as the story was unfolded. It had to end the way it did.Foxx was excellent. Just great. I've only seen him in one or two other things, comedy of course, and had no idea he could do such a tremendous job in a dramatic role. Now I'm dying to see him in Ray.I'd highly recommend this film.

My one word review of Michael Mann's 'Collateral' is "Crisp." Such a professional piece of work; no bells and/or whistles, just super solid crafting. The acting performances from Cruise, Foxx, and Smith are pitch-perfect, with Cruise grabbing the title of 'biggest surprise' as he more than pulls off the bad guy act while shading the character of 'Vincent' with some humanity.Mann's direction embodies the idea of camera as innocent documenter and not the camera as fully involved character. We are shown what happens, the scenes are framed well to properly convey the evolving story, but Mann does not dress things up with unnecessary trickery. And, at least for this film, that methodology pays off handsomely.

Review title: The cast and plot make this a decent movie
Review_body: Tom Cruise and Jamie Foxx make an awkward, but none the less entertaining duo in this action/thriller hybrid. The movie has very few dry parts, and has you constantly guessing what will happen next. The character development is outstanding, as Cruise and Foxx's characters learn a lot from each other. My favorite thing about the movie was the sudden plot twist during the end, that had me on edge and not blinking until the climax had ended. Formula wise, i'd say the movie is about 40% action and 60% thriller, their is quite a few action scenes although most of them are fairly brief. All in all, this is a good overall movie, if your fans of the cast or genre it's worth seeing.8/10

The gun scene in the nightclub is absolutely phenomenal - what with the thumping music, intense lights and screens, the scene really builds itself up, and everything seems to go unnoticed! i think this is an amazing scene, and i saw it in a large group and everyone seemed to be absolutely mesmerised by what they saw. One thing I have to say though - Tom Cruise when he starts 'power-running' and jumps onto the train as well - how 'Terminator 2' was that?! Absolutely LOVED Collateral. Quite unpredictable. It kept me transfixed, and the music and cinematography were mixed together really well. One of the best soundtracks I've heard for a long time.

Review title: Great performance in acting, but a feeling of déjà vu.
Review_body: Collateral was and remains the first thriller directed by Michael Mann after his masterpiece : Heat. In this regard, Collateral appeared to me as the revealing of a temporary lack of inspiration. I have been disappointed since Collateral seems to be in many ways a pale carbon copy of Heat. I don't say that the similarities between the two movies were not intentional : for instance Heat starts in a station and ends along the lanes of LAX whereas Collateral starts in LAX and ends in a station that could even be the one used for the running of Heat. That obvious symmetry was an implied reference, whether to satisfy the fans or to highlight the tragic side of the short-lived characters ? I don't know. An other similarity : two men, who don't know each other, who are apparently opposed in everything, find out what they have in common before ending up killing each other. In Heat the communion between the predator an the prey was credible and genuine. But in Colateral, the characters just do not match. By trying to bring Heat's emotions back to life, Michael Mann has reused the same dramatic features exaggerating them. A cop and a robber can grow aware that they are leading the same kind of life on "opposite sides of the law". In Collateral the scriptwriter chose a cab driver and a hit-man! If only Jamie Foxx' character suffered from the Stockholm syndrome! But it is not even the case.Last but not least there is a main difference to point out : the rewarding role of women. In Heat the parts of Diane Venora, Amy Brenneman and Ashley Judd helped us to picture the situation of family breakdown and personal failures the leading characters experienced. In Collateral the character played by beautiful Jada Pinkett Smith is only designed to lead the story to an end that you can see coming a mile off.5/10 because Michael Mann is better than that.
Ono of my favourite movie of all time., it's make you enjoy every moment , and tom cruise just did well , it's great movie and I recommend everyone who wasn't watch it to make it movie of the night.

An excellent film that shows to me how talented Michael Mann is at what he does, and that what he does is very focused on certain themes. I was astounded, but really happy that it is in my mind, as good as Heat - a great couple of stories, with great actors holding their own in both.It's a story that begins with a man on a mission to assassinate set against a man whose life is passing him by, because he never really stood up for himself.A story that ends with a man who dies just as he's realising where his mission has led him, but who doesn't know how to stand down, killed by the hand of the man who showed him where that mission destroyed his personal choice. But the assassin who dies only died at the hand of that man, because he taught him how the assassin's mind works.And it made me cry... tears at the scene when he dies. And it's made me cry before again, tears at the scene when he dies...when I saw my first Michael Mann film, Heat.A story that begins with man on a mission to pull heists set against a man whose life is passing him by, because he's committed to hunting murderers.A story that ends with a man who dies just as he's realising he has to escape the mission he's spent his life committed to, but who refuses to stand down, killed by the hand of the man who showed him what life could be if he ended his mission. But the heister who died only died at the hand of that man, because he taught him how the heister's mind works.In them both, there are so many similarities, not just the central theme. The denouement of both unveils the driving forces of the two central characters, and how those forces are unbalanced by their interaction with each other. And he unravels this showing strengths and weaknesses in both men, blurring the edges of the standard good guy / bad guy relationship, by illustrating more of an insight.

the film is beautifully photographed and edited (LA never looked better at night)but the script takes too many dramatic licenses-sometimes the film is incomprehensible-Tom Cruise looks good and acts well in a different kind of image (other good alternatives as a hit man would have been Nicholas cage or Alec Baldwin)-perhaps the producers forced the director to submit to the demands of the box office and end the film as it is(compare to the classic James Cagney gangster movies of the past which still continue to haunt us)-nevertheless Michael Mann is a brilliant technician and imaginative director who is sure to hit the bull's eye with a tighter script.

But that's typical of Michael Mann, who can be very, very stylish indeed. But the character development, such as it is, is shallow and unbelievable. The conversations between Cruise and Foxx are meant to be profound, but are so banal they barely qualify as sophomoric. Foxx's performance is solid, but unspectacular, unless you want to give him extra credit for rising above the script. Tom Cruise is, as usual, Tom Cruise. If you like Tom Cruise you won't be disappointed. Mark Ruffalo and Javier Bardem elevate the film briefly in minor roles. Bardem's scene in particular is a gem. If you love Mann's previous films, help yourself. Otherwise, pass. There was more action, emotion, and character development in "The Invincibles" -- and that film was equally stylish to boot.

Collateral is a masterpiece of American cinema. Jamie Foxx is Max, a Los Angeles cab driver with dreams of his own limo company, "Island Limo". After twelve years on the job he has become quite gifted at discerning the most intimate details of his passengers' lives... just a glance at their clothes, and he knows.His worldly insight manages to tear down the defenses of one of his passengers, a State Attorney played by Jada Pinkett Smith, who graces him with her phone number. Max hasn't even begun to revel in the pleasure of possessing the beautiful attorney's digits when he gets his next passenger, Tom Cruise as Vincent, a slick hit-man in town for a night of killing.When a body drops out of a fourth story window and onto Max's cab, he becomes an unwilling partner on Vincent's murder spree. Director Michael Mann (The Insider, Ali) does a masterful job manipulating texture and tone throughout the movie, taking us to settings as diverse as a junkie's apartment, a penthouse, a hospital room, and a smoky jazz club, all the while making the city of angels a central character in the story.The soundtrack is also excellent, with a mixture of popular music and ambient tracks perfectly-timed and synced to the story... tribal drumbeats during the chase scenes, haunting rock ballads at pivotal moments, and one track that reminded this viewer of the scene at the other end of Tom Cruise's career, when he drives his father's Porsche out of the garage in "Risky Business" to the accompaniment of a thumping synth track. A bizarre side-note, I know.As the movie builds to a climax, the police are hunting for Max, believing he is the one on a killing spree, and Vincent stalks his final victim in a blacked-out high-rise office to a backdrop of the brilliant LA skyline, reflected in multiplicity by the office's dozens of glass cubicles.Tom Cruise, Jamie Foxx, and Jada Pinkett Smith all rise to the occasion in Collateral, and together they transcend their previous appearances on film. Mark Ruffalo gives a good performance as the cop who knows everything is not what it seems.There are a few minor plot points which didn't sufficiently suspend my disbelief (like when Max agrees to take Vincent the vicious hit-man to see his Mother in the hospital), but overall this is a fantastic movie.Troy Dayton

Review title: A truly well thought out script
Review_body: Just saw this on DVD. 11/03/05 Real edge-of-your-seat stuff. A challenge to Leon (Luc Besson). Direction is good, but who can beat Luc Besson? The real power of this movie is the script. Every movie seems to have a bit where 'everyone has a heart to heart' then it's on with the action. This script however segments on several occasions between action and reason. The action getting more dramatic as the film progresses and the relationship between the passenger and driver, unfurls superbly. Total suspense. At the conclusion one is left still thinking. Thank you Mr. Beattie for the trill of this spectacle.Acting by key players superb throughout. Though the 'F' word uttered by Mr. Cruse should have been cut, one can tell he's not use to it by the taint of the sound in his voice, a he plays too cool a customer to get agitated, but what a performance - totally convincing.A new action/thriller favourite!

Last time i saw a movie this good was ,10 years ago 'the Grifters'. I cant believe its (not butter) a mainstream movie! this small but perfectly crafted movie is a joy. From its low key, muted cinematography to the unadorned , restrained quality story-telling it entertains.Collateral Honey , you were robbed! Utmost respect for Ray Charles, he remains always, a Titan in 2oth century music. Documenting his life is worthy & long overdue. However for me this movie is the oneJamie Foxx deserved an Oscar for.All movie drama should tell a story well without extra immaterial unhealthy garnish.I'm glad Tom Cruise gets to show the world again that he can in fact act and commits with unexpected skill to a meaty 3d character best ever. He plies his craft humbly and with empathy for his fellow movie makers. Jada Pinket-Smith chisels out a living breathing woman and blends seamlessly into the mix of a (living,breathing) believable story.Jamie Foxx gifts us a non-stereotype of a man who lives down the road from you or you or me.He is the structural beam for our journey into a story more than sum of its parts, and guess what we cant even tell hes doing it! We are with, the people in this story and share their rough ride. For me this film touches that ,that which is inside of us. Its big and small,its all feelings at once ;situated deep inside and i don't care what its called.So I guess this movie is a gift and all about giving. The actors are allowed to ACT , together! And tell a story with dignity.We the watchers are allowed to think, be independent and marvel at things we do and don't understand, but HELL we want to try!The final gift for me in this unpretentious art is that for the first time in o so long i am allowed to fall in love with the characters (in all their perfectly flawed humanity);and savour a square meal of a story in a movie that is for anybody & everyone. Not such ordinary food for masses of individuals.

Review title: A man's gotta do what a man's gotta do
Review_body: I had high hopes for this film, as I am a big fan of Mann's "Heat", "Miami Vice", "Thief" and saw that this could be another urban thriller with thought and brains behind it. Of course it was! As a thriller this film works quite well, but if that's all that you are after. A simple thrill, you're missing a lot of the subtle points with this one. Max is a simple, unhappy working-man who has been driving a cab "temporarily" for over a decade, whilst he is dreaming about starting a limosinecompany. Vincent is a professional hit-man and sees no problem with what he does. The world around them is cold, distant, indifferent and very, very hard to get along with. One has to adapt or fall into shadow and self deceit. When Vincent says "I do this for a living!" the message is clear. Vincents lines are not just random, true words to make you smile (Like some of Tyler Durden's words of wisdom in "Fight Club"), or feel sad. They really paint a picture of what the world has come too. All this philosophy is gracefully placed on and around an excellent action experience. The actors are doing some of their finest work, Tom Cruise is perfect for the role and does a masterful, physical performance. Why Cruise fits so well might be because he has played the typical "professional" so many times before. Doctors, lawyers, spies and even more lawyers. Now the idealistic young man is all grown up, and see what became of him! Jamie Foxx is brilliant when he gets to play roles that demand jokes and loudness, but he handles a low-voiced man under pressure perhaps even better. Hope to see a lot more of him, and I'm pretty damn sure we will. The music plays a big part in this film, all of it might not be my/your taste, but it adds to the whole feeling of a city at night. As if we are hearing a car stereo running. The taxi's radio perhaps? In a car at night, sometimes a song you normally would never like sounds great or fits your mood perfectly. The film was shot using Digital Video, which some people hate. I love it when it fits the context like it does beautifully here. The close and personal-scenes as well as the action scenes get a sort of nakedness. Also the shots of Los Angeles are some of the most beautiful and atmospheric I've ever seen of a city. Flying high among the buildings or following the road closely it really looks spectacular all the way. If you feel, like many others I hear, you don't quite like the ending, I believe you have missed a few of the points along the way. About the compassionate man standing up against indifference, that there is hope, what the woman represents, or perhaps just a few of the things that Vincent said earlier in the film. Anyway this is a great film.Either I like, or don't like. This one I really like, 10/10.

The story is not interestingly Topsy-turvy and it doesn't REALLY arc well...it tries several times but it just never gets there. All in all, though I've always enjoyed Michael Mann's films, I have to say that this was terrible. Too bad so many good actors, excluding Tom Cruise of course were wasted on this film. It's become obvious that the producers in Hollywood are positively clueless as to WHAT moves audiences in this day and age. It's too bad, considering so many great films came out of other periods in history when the world was in a precarious state of flux.

Review title: Michael Mann's most recent work of art!
Review_body: Two separate worlds collide for a night when a smooth but very simple taxi cab driver Max, (Jamie Fox) picks up his next customer Vincent (Tom Cruise), a very talented fast moving hit man on a killing spree through the moonlit streets of downtown Los Angeles. All goes according to plan except for his last hit when his cabbie Max gets involved. Collateral shows that the value of human life is irreplaceable and significant to most people, and that to some people life is shallow, expendable and unimportant.Collateral allows its viewers to interact with the lives of two complete opposite individuals and the conflict that is created between Vincent and Max. The film displays the beauty of life in many variations, for example Michael Mann shows that underneath all the materialistic and separations of different society levels that connections are made between people of all likes makes and models. Perhaps the following may be a bit of a spoiler, however in the beginning of the film viewers witness this connection with the interaction that takes place between Max a cab driver and Annie a federal prosecutor. But from a different perspective Michael Mann reveals that certain people are disconnected from the wonderful gifts of life. Mann reflects this disconnect through Vincent's character thought process and actions.Another film that helps to reinforce Collateral's theme for example is the movie The Professional, Also known as "Leon", 1994. The main character Leon a hit man plays a similar role like that of Tom Cruise. Leon who is a very dangerous hit man also allows his audience to view his very intimate softer side; viewers can witness this affection with his relationship to Matilda a young girl who he desperately protects with his life. Collateral displays the wonderful talent of director Michael Mann. The majority of the movie is shot in low-key lighting, to signify the intense intimacy between the city, Vincent and Max. A great scene to help reinforce this statement is when Max and Vincent get pulled over by the police and Vincent is warning Max that he must loose the police and talk his way out of the dire situation. The scene is shot in low-key lighting with a close-up shot of Max's facial expressions and in the frame a selective focused shot of Vincent in the back seat of the cab. For most individual's life is a priceless gift, however some are on this earth to seek and destroy it, Collateral's stars Tom Cruise and Jaime Fox's characters reflect a great example of this dilemma.

This is a wonderful piece of artwork. Its plot is well knitted, and the actors play their parts in a nearly flawless manner. No other film captures the city of LA as well as this. Nor does any other film capture the night hours in such a beautiful and distinguished way. This might be attributed to director Micheal Mann's excellent directoral abilitys or by his choice to use digital cameras to record much of this film. They not only capture the night better, but they give you much more realistic look and feel to a film such as this. I recommend that everyone watch this film at least once in their life, it is a beautiful and violent look at the world we live in.

Review title: There are six billion people on the planet and you're getting bent out of shape cause of one fat guy?
Review_body: The name Tom Cruise has become synonymous with the word 'wooden' over the last few years, a label not unfairly bestowed considering he's never really starred in a world class film, yet remains one of the highest paid movie affiliates of all time. He innately performs extremely similar roles in all his films, the virtuous and admirable American hero that all women love and that all men want to be. So it comes as a surprise to learn that he takes on a rare villainous role in this film, the role of a sociopathic hit-man tasked with murdering five people in a nights work. Jamie Foxx is cast as the routine taxi driver with aspirations to become something more, but is held back lack of ambition and a reliance on security and routine.Even more surprising than Tom Cruise' role is the fact that this is the finest performance he's ever committed to a film. His depiction as the brutally proficient killer is scarily inspiring. He underplays his role, abandoning his self imposing demeanour for simple efficiency and the end result is that he makes a one man army capable of engaging multiple opponents and defeating them all seem very believable. His execution of the Mozabique drill is highly accurate and it's inclusion gives Vincent a higher degree of realism that if he was merely blindly shooting his way through scores of assailants without injury like any standard Bond film. The rare interludes that provide his philosophical insight into sociology also give Vincent that extra depth that separates him from the standard action villain.Jamie Foxx similarly provides an excellent contribution through his subtle portrayal of an average cabbie thrust into a mortally threatening situation where the slightest mistake would undoubtedly result in his death. His initial bewilderment to the situation is excellently executed, as is his careful transition to assertive man of action, influenced by his constant proximity to Vincent. The relationship between him and Cruise gives the film a certain degree of depth rarely committed to the action thriller genre. The whole film is ridden with carefully laden undertones depicting the delicate balance between planning and improvisation that dominate everyones life. Both characters are extremes of each, and their struggle to irrevocably find a balance between them is superbly scripted.Furthermore, Michael Manns directing is nothing short of stellar. His mix up of camera shots and fast edit cuts give the film a excellently balanced pace, involving the audience with the quick transition through scenes but not storming through the film at such a pace that it compromises necessary detail.Overall this is an excellent film definitely worth watching, one which Tom Cruise undoubtedly deserved an Oscar Nomination for but bafflingly failed to receive.8.3/10

Review title: Best Movie I Have Ever Seen
Review_body: Collateral is by far the best action movie I have ever seen in my entire life. The actors, the plot, and the action in the movie are all just wonderful and exciting. One major reason why this movie was so amazing was because of the outstanding actors that were in the film, which included Tom Cruise, Jamie Foxx and Jada Pinkett Smith. I absolutely loved every aspect of this film. I watch a lot of movies and this is the only movie that was worthy enough to buy on DVD. Basically the movie is about Max (Jamie Foxx) is a failed comedy writer living in Los Angeles who makes a living as a cab driver. Max also has a lifelong dream of owning his own limo company called "Island Limo," where only the best service will exist. The entire movie focuses on one very chaotic night for Max, as he figures out that his cab passenger (Tom Cruise) turns out to be a contract killer, committing a series of hits as Max can do nothing but drive. Ultimately, it's up to Max to stop the killer from executing his last witness as well as himself. The action sequence in this movie has something different about it. It has a unique style of action that I have never seen before; it's just beautiful to watch. Michael Mann, the director of the film did an excellent job staging the action and all the relative events. I believe that this is a great movie with a lot to look forward to. There's nothing more to say about this film except, GO SEE IT.

I saw this movie when one of my friends came over and brought it. This movie....wow, this movie was so awesome, a true classic for me! It is interesting right from the beginning to the end, yet the death of Vincent was a bit modest. I'm no critic or anything, by all means, but his death could have been more elaborated. I did not know he got shot until I saw the blood on his side, very interesting though, he didn't seem to be in pain. Quite a valiant death, in my opinion, too valiant. I admire the scriptwriter's spunk with the unforgettable remarks of Max and Vincent. One I favor most is the scene where the fat man falls onto Max's taxi, when Vincent comes back out and Max confronts him about it, Vincent didn't kill the fat man, the bullets and the fall killed him. I don't know how Tom Cruise kept a straight face at that moment, even after all his years of acting and practice, I could never do that! Someone would have to threaten me with the loss of my life in order for me to keep it straight!Another thing, Tom Cruise will no doubt age gracefully since he looks quite good with gray hair. Professional, yet simple with a sort of laid-back feel. I honestly thought he would be the hero at the beginning of the movie! Maybe someone else thought so, too!In conclusion, I think this movie deserved more publicity than it got, perhaps it was that a taxi driver's cab being hijacked was a bit too outrageous, or that maybe that the ending was sparse, I do not know. I also liked the music, being a musician ('cello), I enjoy listening to the music in movies. I recognized a piece by Bach toward the beginning of the movie, it was in a jazz format with the the bass playing the 'cello part and the piano playing the orchestra part. A great arrangement, it was. It was a great movie that I enjoyed and I hope many other people enjoyed it, too.

Review title: Best thriller of the last 10 years
Review_body: I honestly think this film is probably: a) the best Tom Cruise film, because, lets be honest, there aren't that many good Tom Cruise films, and b) the best action thriller since 'Heat' in '95. Although it's not as good as 'Heat', it is pretty close. The two main actors are brilliant in it - Jamie Foxx showing the kind of acting that got his the Oscar for 'Ray', and Tom Cruise showing that he is better as a bad guy (like 'Interview With A Vampire'). To back this up, the supporting cast are good as well - led by Jada Pinkett Smith - and the soundtrack constantly pumps out modern rock and dance tunes. Even though there aren't as many twists as there should be in a good thriller, it makes up for it with great action and great acting. If anyone knows a better thriller in the since 'Heat', please let me know!

May be I'm reading this film wrong, but Vincent must be the world's worst movie hit man! How and why did he really manage to fumble his first hit out of the window? Being a hit man he would/should have managed it quietly. Why the so public hits? Nightclub? And he uses a cab, so the driver is a loose cannon as the film showed. Could he have not just used a car that could not be traced to him? All points to him wanting to get caught/dead but the film doesn't seem to fully explore this. If you want to see a hit-man movie then Leon remains the best and Vincent could learn a thing or two from Leon! Cruise's performance in the film is also at his wooden best, though Jamie Foxx does save the day. Being a Michael Mann film there is some great cinematography, but overall one of his worst movies I think.

I'm not a big fan of Tom Cruise, so I didn't start watching with high hopes. I don't think I've ever been more wrong in my life.Story: Jamie Foxx plays Max, a longtime running cab driver, who picks up Vincent, played by Tom Cruise, who says he needs to make a few stops within the night, and if it's all done by a certain time, Max earns a considerable amount of money. Shortly after the first stop, it's revealed that Vincent is a contract killer, and all the stops are his next victims. As this review is spoiler free, I won't go into further detail, but all I can say is that this story is extremely well written.Characters: Tom Cruise is very convincing as an assassin, and he and Foxx's character have a strange sort of chemistry that just works out well. The supporting characters do their parts well too.Screenplay: The cab scenes are relaxing in a strange sort of way. The camera wobbles while they're in it, and though that may sound crude, it feels like you're in the cab with them. The action scenes are shot extremely well too.Overall: This film is just awesome for anyone looking for a suspense film with a hint of action that has a good plot. Even if you're not a fan of Jamie Foxx or Tom Cruise, this film will make you forget that. And since you can pick up the DVD brand new for about 7 bucks today, I'd definitely check it out sometime. 9.5/10
